Moreover with the tight economic condition deteriorating and her 2 children still young made Ayu Putu decide to be diligent in pig farming which has been a family tradition since generations. Her husband’s income as a farmer is felt to be not sufficient to provide for the family’s expenses. With the motivation to assist her husband Ayu Putu decided to borrow from DINARI through the KIVA program to increase her capital to fund her pig farming. With the initial loan 4 breeding pigs Ayu once again purchase 5 pigs with the loan from DINARI. Coincidentally, Ayu’s pig pen are adequately permanent adequate to accommodate many pigs. Ayu is very serious in the pig farming because income from the sale is large. After 5 months of breeding usually result in income of Rp.500.000,- (about USD 54) each month. This will definitely aid fulfilling the family’s expenses.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Meski masih berusia muda untuk seorang ibu rumah tangga, tidak membuat Ayu Putu bersantai-santai dengan kehidupannya. Apalagi dengan himpitan ekonomi yang semakin berat dan ditambah harus menghidupi kedua anaknya yang masih kecil-kecil membuat Ayu Putu memutuskan untuk menekuni usahanya sebagai peternak babi yang memang sudah digeluti oleh keluarganya secara turun temurun. Penghasilan suaminya yang seorang petani dirasa masih belum cukup memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Dengan motivasi membantu suaminya inilah Ayu Putu memutuskan untuk meminjam ke DINARI melalui program KIVA sehingga modalnya akan bertambah untuk usaha ternak babinya. Dengan modal awal 4 ekor babi penggemukan Ayu kembali membeli 5 ekor lagi dengan menggunakan modal dari DINARI. Kebetulan kandang babi Ayu sudah cukup permanen sehingga mampu menampung banyak babi. Ayu memang sangat serius menekuni usaha ternak babinya karena keuntungan yang didapat cukup besar dari hasil penjualannya. Selama 5 bulan pemeliharaan nantinya diharapkan bisa mendatangkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 500.000,- setiap bulannya. Tentunya hal ini akan sangat membantu memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and supplies (Membeli anak babi dan pakannya)

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suriani

texts.id:
With the limitation, Ketut Suriani did not surrender to the situation. Determined to help her husband, a farmer, in fulfilling the family’s expenses and her 3 children’s livelihood. Ketut Suraini took the decision to be more active in her pig farming. With the initial capital 2 breeding pigs then Ketut submit an application for a loan to DINARI with the KIVA program when available agreed to provide additional funding which will be used to purchase 4 piglets for breeding and pig feed. Because already in pig farming for a long time with adequate pig pen and with training on good pig farming methods and guaranteed financing from the DINARI staff Ketut has great hope from this activity. Income generated after breeding approximately 5 months estimate at Rp.500.000,- (about USD54) per month. From this income it is hoped that it will cover the children’s education expenses and daily needs.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Dengan keterbatasan yang dimilikinya tidak membuat Ketut Suriani menyerah dengan keadaanya. Bertekad membantu suaminya yang sebagai petani dalam memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga serta menghidupi ketiga anaknya, Ketut Suriani mengambil keputusan lebih giat dalam menekuni usaha ternak babi. Dengan modal awal 2 ekor babi penggemukan kemudian Ketut mengajukan permohonan pinjaman modal ke DINARI dengan program KIVA yang ada dan disetujui untuk memberikan suntikan modal yang akan digunakannya untuk membeli 4 ekor bibit penggemukan lagi serta membeli pakan babi. Karena sudah lama menekuni usaha ternak babi dengan kandang yang cukup memadai serta ditambah pelatihan tentang cara memelihara babi yang baik dan manajemen keuangan keluarga dari staf DINARI Ketut sangat berharap banyak dari usahanya ini. Keuntungan yang dapat diperoleh setelah pemeliharaan selama kurang lebih 5 bulan diperkirakan sebesar Rp. 500.000,- per bulannya. Dari hasil ini diharapkan bisa memenuhi biaya pendidikan anaknya serta untuk biaya hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and supplies (Membeli bibit babi dan pakannya)

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a 42-year-old married woman with two children aged 23 and 15. She has owned a small curio shop since 2006. Every day,she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US450 from her sales.

In the past,Catherine has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her shop.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Sehr

texts.en: Sehr Baji is the wife of M. Shehzad and has been living in an area named Shalimar in Lahore, Pakistan.  She owns a three-room brick house. She is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is a mother of three sons. All of her sons are in kindergarten. Her husband runs a garment shop in a place named Panorama situated in a market area. He sells men's garments only. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She bought a house from the profit of her first loan. Now she is applying for a loan to enhance her husband's garment business.

loans.use: To buy more garments

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is a married woman with one child, age 7. She has been a clothes seller since 2001. Every day, she works from 8am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US90 from her sales.

Prisca now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Rasheeda

texts.en: Rasheeda Baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of five children: three daughters and two sons. Her daughters are married while her two sons help their father in his business. Her husband makes steel chains and sells them in various markets. Rasheeda Baji is a housewife and helps her husband during the making of steel chains. She successfully completed her three previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). With the profit of those loans she bought a 3-Canals plot. Now she is applying for a loan to buy an automatic chain making machine worth Pk.Rs. 1,30,000.

loans.use: to buy an electric machine

loans.name: Teddy's Agape Group

texts.en:
Teddy is a married woman with a four-year-old child. She became a charcoal seller in 2005. Every day, she works from 9am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US53 from her sales.

In the past, Teddy has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business.Teddy now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal inventory.

loans.name: Naziraan

texts.en: Naziraan Baji is the wife of Mr. A. and lives with her family in a city named Lahore, Paksitan. Naziraan Baji owns a three-room brick house. She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Naziraan Baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her children. Her husband has an iron and steel business. He makes tools from iron and steel and sells them in the market. Mr. A. has been in this profession for the last 35 years. Naziraan Baji successfully completed her two previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more steel and iron for her husband's business.

loans.use: To buy iron and steel

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is a married woman with 2 children aged 10 and 1. She has been selling tomatoes since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US550 from her sales.

Magdalena now hopes for a loan to buy more tomato inventory.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Irshaad

texts.en: Irshaad Baji is the wife of M. N. who has been in the army for the last 25 years. She is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has been living in an area called "Jani Pura chowk" near Shalimar, Lahore, for the last 15 years. She owns a three-room brick house. She is the owner of two grocery shops which are situated near her house. She is the mother of six children: three sons and three daughters. One of her sons is a driver, another son runs a grocery shop, and the last son is studying. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Paksitan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more material (lentils, cooking oil, rice) for her son's grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy material for a grocery shop

loans.name: Rehema's Wema Group

texts.en:
Rehema is a 34-year-old married woman with three children, ages between 2 months and 12 years. She has owned a small shop since 2007. Every day, she works from 1am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US90 from her sales.

Rehema now hopes for a loan to buy more flour, oil, charcoal, and yeast for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Christina.

loans.use: To increase shop inventory

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: Rukhsana Baji is the wife of Mr. Rafaqat A. and lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-story brick house. She is the mother of four children: three daughters and one son. Her son is enrolled in a local school in the neighborhood. Her husband has an embroidery business and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. She is a housewife and helps her husband make embroidered dresses. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy an embroidery machine for her husband so that he can extend his orders and earn more profit.

loans.use: To buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Inoyatullo

texts.ru:
IInoyatullo A. lives in Dushanbe city. He is 30 years old and married. He does not have children yet. Inoyatullo is a businessman. He sells men's clothes. He purchases goods in Bishkek city. Currently, he does not have enough money in order to increase the variety of goods he sells. This is why he came to us for help. Inoyatullo would like to receive a loan in order to increase the assortment of goods. He would like to repay the loan within 12 months. This loan will help him attract new customers and gain additional profit. Despite the fact that he does not have children, he lives with a large family. His family includes parents, brothers and sisters. He has to work a lot, because he is the oldest son. His family is very friendly.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Азизов Иноятулло проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст 30 лет , женат . Детей пока не имеет. Занимается бизнесом в сфере продаж. Торгует мужской одеждой. За товаром ездит в город Бишкек. Но его оборотной суммы не хватает для того , чтобы разнообразить ассортимент товара. Поэтому он обратился к нам за помощью. Хочет получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев. Этот кредит поможет ему привлечь новых клиентов и получить дополнительную прибыль. Не смотря на то , что у него нет детей, он живет в очень большой семье . где живут родители , братья и сестра. Поэтому ему приходится много работать , так как он старший сын. Но все-таки у них очень дружная семья.

loans.use: Increase the assortment of goods

loans.name: Selina's Mkombozi Group

texts.en:
Selina is a married woman with one child, aged 24. She sells vegetables every day from 6am to 12pm. She can earn a monthly profit of about $US300 from her sales.

Selina now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwajuma, who has a business selling tomatoes.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: Naseem Baji is a widow of M. A.. She is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She has been living in an area called "Jani Pura chowk" near Shalimar, Lahore, for the last 7 years. She owns a three-room brick house. She is the mother of eight children: four sons and four daughters. Two sons run a shop of ready-made garments in a market named "Panorama." One of her sons has been in the crockery business for 10 years, and the last son is studying. She is applying for a loan for her son's crockery business.

loans.use: To buy more crockery

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.ru:
Zuhro H. has been in business for a long time. She has been selling food items for the past 10 years. She lives in Dushanbe city with her family. Zuhro is married and has five children. She is 47 years old. Zuhro came to us for a loan in order to increase her variety of goods. This will help her increase the amount of products she sells; this way, she will be able to develop her business further. She must do this because this business is the only source of income for her family. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Холова Зухро бизнесмен со стажем . Уже 10 лет она занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Живет в городе Душанбе со своей семьей. Она замужем и унее пятеро детей. Возраст 47 лет. Обратилась к нам за кредитом , чтобы на полученные деньги увеличить ассортимент товара. Это поможет ей увеличить объем продаваемой продукции и таким образом она сможет развивать свой бизнес дальше. Это сделать ей необходимо , так как ее бизнес является единственным источником дохода ее семьи.Погасить кредит она планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase more goods

loans.name: Neema's Neema Group

texts.en:
Neema is a 28-year-old married woman with three children, ages 2 months to 12 years. She has owned a small shop since 2003. Every day, she works from 1am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US225 from her sales.

Neema now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling vegetables and fruits and clothes.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Peruzamoh

texts.ru:
Peruzamoh Parvosova lives in the city of Nurek. She trades. Peruzamoh has a spot on the city market where she sells children's clothing. She plans to increase turnover of her goods by receiving a loan. This way, she will be able to receive greater profits. Peruzamoh plans to pay back the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Парвозова Перузамох проживает в городе Нурек .Занимается торговлей . Имеет торговую точку на рынке города , где продает детскую одежду. Планирует увеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита. Таким образом она сможет увеличить товарооборот и увеличить прибыль от бизнеса. Погасить кредит сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase the turnover of goods

loans.name: Helena's Jerusalem Group

texts.en:
Helena is a 46-year-old married woman with three children, aged 16, 20, and 26. She has been a clothes seller since 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US100 from her sales.

Helena now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Martha, who has a business dealing with farming.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is 34 years old, married, and the father of 4 children.  He lives in a town close to Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. He owns a coffee shop in the area where he lives. Presently, Mahmoud needs a loan of USD 1,200 to pay the overdue amount on the second-hand car he purchased in order to guarantee better livelihoods for his wife and children. This is the first time Mahmoud has requested a loan from Al Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner].

loans.use: Complete the payment of the car he purchased

loans.name: Abdurasul.

texts.ru:
Abdurasul B. lives in the city of Yavan, in one of its outlying areas. The life in his community is very difficult. He is 58 and he has lived his whole life there. He is married and has six children. Abdurasul is a teacher in a lyceum № 1 in Yavan. Additionally, almost everyone in his community has farm animals at home. Abdurasul has one bull. He decided to ask for a loan and purchase one more young, well-bred bull. He will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Бобоалиев Абдурасул проживает в городе Яван , в одном из дальних кишлаков. Жизнь в его кишлаке очень тяжелая. Ему 58 лет и всю жизнь он прожил там. Он женат и имеет шестерых детей. Работает учителем в лицее № 1 города Яван. Кроме того почти у каждого жителя кишлака есть домашнее хозяйство. Вот и у него имеется один бычок. Он решил получить кредит и купить еще одного молодого , породистого бычка , а погасить кредит сможет в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a bull

loans.name: Dinna

texts.en:
Dinna is a 24-year-old married woman with one child, aged 2 years. She sells clothes and shoes. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US225.

Dinna now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Serng

texts.en:
Mr. Serng S. is 27 years old bricklayer. He lives in Omperl Commune, Siem Reap Province. His wife, Mrs. Choeun Sat is a 26-year-old farmer. S. and his wife live with two children, both of whom are too young and to attend school. Everyday S. spends a lot for traveling to work and therefore he wants to reduce travel expenses and save the money for his family’s support.

S. would like to request a loan $550 to purchaS. a motorcycle to uS. for traveling to work. S. plans to uS. the remainder of the loan to purchaS. fertilizer to uS. for his wife's vegetable crops. The loan will help expand their business and hopefully increaS. their income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use as traveling to work

loans.name: Abed

texts.en: Abed, 38 years old, lives with his wife and 3 children in a town close to Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. Abed works in  stone flooring maintenance and has been a micro-credit beneficiary of the Institution for the past 2 years. The first time Abed requested a loan from Al Majmoua, it was to buy tools for the improvement of his business. He successfully repaid his loan on time. He now hopes to receive a loan for the amount of US$ 1,200 to purchase an electric power generator. This equipment will allow Abed to offer more services to his clients.

loans.use: Purchase an electric power generator

loans.name: Huor

texts.en: Mrs. Huor N. is a villager in Trakiet Village in Kampong Speu Province. She owns a small grocery store in the village. Her husband, Mr. Vannak Vuth, assists in his wife's business. Mrs. Huor N. is 38 years old and the mother of eight children, five of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right in the picture. To support her business, Mrs. Huor N. needs to buy grocery products from the Kampong Speu market.  She now faces a problem because she does not have a motorbike for transporting goods from the market to resell. Thus, Mrs. Huor N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for transporting goods to resell in the local market.

loans.name: Abed

texts.en:
Abed, 32 years old and a married man and father of 3 children, lives in the area of Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. Abed manages two businesses at the same time: he is a barber and hair designer for men but he also owns a small restaurant where youth from the villages come to get a sandwich and play "babyfoot" [table football].

Because of the ever increasing cost of living in Lebanon, the income provided by one business alone was no longer enough to answer the requirements of his family. Thus, Abed requested from Al Majmoua, last year, a loan to open a little restaurant, parallel to his barber shop. He successfully opened the snack bar and repaid the loan on time. He currently needs a loan in the amount of US$ 500 to purchase a new meat grill in order to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase a new meat grill for the snack bar

loans.name: Magreth

texts.en:
Magreth is a single woman with a one-year-old child. She owns and has run a small food shop since 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US90 from her sales.

Magreth now hopes for a loan to buy more inventory, including rice, maize flour, beans, and sugar.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mrs. Suon S. owns a grocery store in Ankrorng Village in Kampong Speu Province. Her husband, Mr. Mol Man, is a farmer; he is on the left in the photo. Mrs. Suon S. is 48 years old and the mother of seven children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while two others are attending school. The remaining three are too young to work or study. Previously, she had obtained a loan from AMK to start her current business and she has fully paid it back. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more inventory for her store.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store.

loans.name: Asiah

texts.en:
Asiah is a married woman with a one-year-old child. She has owned a small food shop since 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US175 from her sales.

Asiah now hopes for a loan to buy more items including rice, sugar, and beans for her business.

loans.use: To increase  shop inventory

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Mrs. Man K. lives in Trav Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice and vegetables. Mrs. Man K. is a 56-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while the other is living at home. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Man K. wants her second child to start a motorbike taxi business. She decided to ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike to help reach this goal. Last year, one of her children got typhoid and Mrs. Man K. faced unforeseen expenses. This is the reason why Mrs. Man K. does not have enough money to buy a new motorbike for her child's business.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to start a motorbike taxi business.

loans.name: Norah Semugera’S Group

texts.en:
Norah is the leader of 4 members of a group. She is a 57-year-old widow with 8 children. They are aged between 40 and 23 years. Only one is in school and the rest are working.

She owns a five-room house in which she lives with 5 people, and she takes care of three grandchildren who are orphans. A religious group helps her to pay school dues. She is offering the family two meals a day while tea is rarely taken.

Norah resides and works in a semi-urban slum area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. There is no piped water and electricity at her home. Norah works six days a week and runs a charcoal store at her home. Norah has been involved in this business for the last four years. She buys her merchandise from suppliers who collect it from villages and doesn’t incur any extra transport costs. She attends to an average of ten customers daily and sells to all categories of people.

Her main challenge is that when it rains she gets very few customers as they fear to reach out to her because her home is always flooded. Thieves at times break into her store and competition is also very high.

She has been with MCDT for the last two years and is servicing her fourth loan. Norah has been working with the same group members throughout this period. Her achievements include improved standards of living, ability to pay school fees, expanded business and others.

loans.use: To increase stock in her business

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en: Zahra, 39 years old, lives in the South of Lebanon close to Tyre. She is a young married woman and the mother of three. Her children describe her as a courageous mother. Zahra owns a cosmetics shop. She needs an amount of USD 1,200 to replace her old car. Her car is an important tool for her business, as she travels a lot to find new products or better deals from suppliers. This is the second time that Zahra has requested a loan from Al Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner]. She successfully repaid her previous loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of a new car to replace the old one

loans.name: Mirzosharif

texts.ru:
Mirzosharif A. lives in the city of Yavan. He is a driver. He is married and has six children. In his free time, which he usually has during the week-ends, Mirzosharif buys and sells animals at the local market. He buys a couple of bulls and then resells them at a higher price. He has been in this business for 9 years. In order to increase profit, he needs additional funds. Mirzosharif wants to receive a loan in order to be able to buy and sell more. This way, he would be able to purchase well-bread cows and bulls. He plans to repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer.

Ашуров Мирзошариф проживает одном из кишлаков города Яван. Работает водителем . Женат и имеет шестерых детей. В свободное от работы время , а это обычно в субботу и в воскресенье он выходит на животный рынок и занимается перепродаже скота. Покупает пару бычков подешевле и тут же перепродает по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 9 лет. Для того , чтобы увеличить прибыльность необходимы дополнительные средства. Он хочет получить кредит и увеличить товарооборот. Таким образом он сможет покупать породистых коров и бычков. Погасить кредит он сможет в течение 6 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase the number of animals

loans.name: Bibigul

texts.ru:
Bibigul S. lives in the city of Yavan. She is married and has 4 children. She is 46 years old. Since she was a child she has been raising animals. She has a farm on which she raises cows. She would like to obtain a loan in order to purchase building materials and build a shelter for the cows. This will help her create a better environment for breeding cows and make the shelter ready for the winter. She plans to repay the loan within a 12 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Саидова Бибигуль проживает в городе Яван. Замужем и имеет четверых детей. Возраст 46 лет , и с самого детства занимается животноводством. В данный момент имеет хозяйство , где разводит коров. Сейчас хочет получить кредит , для покупки стройматериалов для пристройки коровника. Это поможет создать лучшие условия для разведения скота , а так же подготовить коровник к зиме. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase building materials

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 34-year-old married woman with 4 children, ages between 2 and 22. She owns a small general store where she works every day. Jane can earn a monthly profit of about $US550 from her sales.

Jane now hopes for a loan to buy more inventory for her store.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Kotognontala (Mutual Compromise) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres de Kotognontala sont des femmes mariées vivant en général dans des familles traditionnelles élargies polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent au quartier Sokala du village de Zambougou Fouta dans le (Région de Ségou République du Mali). Liées par des relations professionnelles, d’amitié et de voisinage, elles exercent le commerce de condiments et de denrées alimentaires. 
Elles achètent généralement les denrées alimentaires sur place (à Zambougou) et dans les villages environnants (tels Dougabougou, Benembougou, Fombougou, Teisserela et Ganssola) pour les stocker au niveau de la concession conjugale. Par contre les condiments sont achetés au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes fréquentant les foires hebdomadaires.
Elles revendent ces articles en détail au comptant et à crédit les jours de foires de façon ambulante ou à domicile. La clientèle est généralement constituée de femmes et d’hommes.
Afin de satisfaire les besoins de leurs clientèles de plus en plus croissants, les membres du groupe Kotognontala ont décidé de demander un prêt de groupe à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 2 sacs de 50 kg de riz, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et 1 sac de haricot. .
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7.500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, renforcer les fonds de commerce et aider dans les charges de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Kotognontala are married women living in general in traditional extended polygamous families with an average age of 42 and 3 children on average. They live in the Sokala neighborhood of the village of Zambougou Fouta in the Ségou Region, Republic of Mali. Linked by ties of profession, friendship, and proximity, they sell condiments and foodstuffs.

They generally purchase the foodstuffs in the village of Zambougou and the surrounding villages such as Dougabougou, Benembougou, Fombougou, Teisserela and Ganssola and store their merchandise in their homes. On the other hand, condiments are bought in the big market in Ségou from wholesalers who come to the weekly market days.

They re-sell these articles retail, for cash or credit, on market days, or door-to-door, or out of their homes. Their clientele is generally made up of women and men.

So as to satisfy the needs of their ever growing clientele, the members of the Kotognontala group have decided to ask for a group loan from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are presently on their first loan.

With this loan they intend to buy 2 sacks of 50 kg each of rice, a large amount of condiments, and a sack of dried beans. They hope to make a monthly average profit of 7.500 FCFA which will be used to make the payments on the loan, to bolster their working capital, and to help cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Gisela

texts.en:
Gisela is a 27-year-old married woman with a 1-year-old child. She has been a clothes seller since 2006. Every day, she works from 1am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US50 from her sales.

Gisela now hopes for a loan to buy more clothing inventory for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Hilal

texts.en: Hilal is 35 years old, married, and the father of 3 children. He lives with his family in the South of Lebanon, close to Tyre. Hilal is a carpenter. He is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase new carpentry tools and hence to expand his business. Hilal has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for the past 2 years and has always repaid his debts on time.

loans.use: Purchase new carpentry tools

loans.name: Mrs. Kung Nin Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, which is made up of 29 members, is located in Ta Skor Village in Kandal Province. All the members are shown in the picture but some of their faces are blocked.  Mrs. Kung N., the village bank president, is a 61-year-old married mother with five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is a government officer. Two others assist their parents' businesses, while the youngest one is enrolled in a local school.   

Mrs. Kung N. sells fish in the local market. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Kung N. wants to expand it.  Therefore, she decided to ask for a loA. to buy more fish to meet her customers' demand. Her husband, Mr. Pech Chea, is a farmer. He always cultivates twice a year. During the rainy season, he cultivates rice; he grows vegetables in the dry season. Mr. Pech Chea now does not face any problems because he has enough farming equipment for the plantation business.

loans.use: To buy more fish to reach her customers' demand.

loans.name: Djiguissèmè (Support) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et quatre enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, généralement des coépouses, les beaux parents, les frères et sœurs et les enfants dans le village de Zogofina préfecture de Ségou quatrième région de la république du Mali.
L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes Djiguisemme est la vente du bois de chauffe et des denrées alimentaires (mil, arachide, haricot, maïs, dah etc.) qu’elles achètent soit sur place ou dans les villages environnants du village de Zogofina (tel à Zenguela et Soignebougou) avec les paysans ravitaillant la ville de Ségou et qui détiennent des permis de coupe de bois.
Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage dans la concession conjugale et vendent généralement le bois de chauffe en détail à une clientèle locale (femmes et hommes) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou et Bamako. 
Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage et très entreprenants dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec un remboursement correct. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 60 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, 3 sacs de graines d’arachide et espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500 FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et surtout renforcer leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Djiguissèmè are all married with an average age of 42 and four children on average. They live in big traditional extended families with their husbands, generally with co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers and sisters, and children in the village of Zogofina, Prefecture of Ségou, fourth region of the Republic of Mali.

The principal business of this Djiguissèmè group of women is the sale of firewood and foodstuffs (millet, peanuts, dried beans, corn, dah--hibiscus blossoms used to make drinks--etc.) which they either buy right in their village or in surrounding villages of Zogofina (such as Zenguela and Soignebougou) and from rural people who supply the town of Ségou and who have permits to cut wood.

They have storerooms in their husbands' compounds and generally sell the firewood retail to a local clientele (women and men) and wholesale to itinerant businessmen who come from the big cities of Ségou et Bamako.

United by bonds of profession or proximity and very enterprising in their economic activities, the members of the group are now on their fourth group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and have reimbursed all loans correctly.

With this loan they intend to buy 60 wagonloads of firewood and 3 sacks of peanuts and hope to make a monthly average profit of 22,500 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, to help support their families, and above all to expand their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood and peanuts

loans.name: Maria's Glory Group

texts.en:
Maria is a married woman with one child, aged 2 years old. She is a clothes seller. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $US140 from her sales.

Maria now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Eliatikiswa, who also has a shop of her own.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is 37 years old. She is married with three children between the ages of 9 and 16. In 2000, she became a drink seller. Everyday, she works from 7 a.m. to 12 p.m. at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $135 from her sales.

Christina now hopes for a loan to buy more soft drinks to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sabougnouman (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
These four members of the Sbougnouman group are on average 38 years old and have four children. They live in the village of Zogofina (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali), in polygynous households with their husbands, co-wives and children. The women share professional ties, kinship, friendship and live in the same neighborhood. They primarily trade in condiments, grains, fresh cow’s milk, pagnes (lengths of brightly-colored African cloth), and firewood. Some aspects of their business are of a daily variety, as in milk, while others are seasonal (grains, wood and condiments, et cetera). To meet the ever-increasing customer demand, they decided to join the loan program at the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, which has granted them three group loans, all repaid in full.

The women in the group often replenish their stock of coarse grains and fresh cow’s milk locally in Zogofina, but at times go to the neighboring villages of Zenguela and Soignebougou for firewood, and to the regional capital of Ségou for condiments, pagnes and rice. With this loan they expect to buy 50 liters of fresh cow’s milk (20 liters per day), 150 kilograms of coarse grains and pulses (millet, peanuts, beans, et cetera), 4 cartloads of firewood, 10 lengths of quality pagne and 300 kilograms of spices and rice.

Products are then generally sold retail for cash or credit on market day at the village square, or both during the day and in the evening from home. Their customers generally consist of women and men coming from other villages to make their purchases in Zogofina. They expect to realize a monthly profit of $67 (30,000 Central African francs), sufficient to make their monthly loan payment, support their families and reinvest in their business.

Translated from French by Joyce, Kiva Volunteer.

Les quatre membres du groupe Sabougnouman ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des foyers polygames avec leurs maris coépouses et enfants dans le village de Zogofina préfecture de Ségou (république du Mali.). Ces femmes sont liées par des relations professionnelles, de parenté, d’amitié et de voisinage. Elles font essentiellement le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de céréales, de lait frais de vache, de pagnes et du bois de chauffe. Les activités menées sont souvent quotidiennes (le lait) ou étalées dans le temps (les céréales, le bois et les condiments etc.). Afin de satisfaire une demande de plus en plus croissante de la clientèle, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso qui accepta de leur accorder trois prêts de groupe, tous correctement remboursés.

Les femmes de groupe se ravitaillent souvent sur place à Zogofina (en céréales sèches et en lait frais de vache), parfois dans les villages environnants (tel Zenguela et Soignebougou en bois de chauffe) et dans la capitale régionale Ségou (en condiments alimentaires, pagnes et en riz). Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt : 50 litres de lait frais de vache (vente quotidienne), 150 kg de céréales sèches (mil haricot arachide etc.) 4 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe 10 pièces de pagnes fancy et 300 kg de condiments et de riz.

Les ventes sont effectuées généralement en détail, au comptant et à crédit les jours de foires, sur la place publique du village et à domicile (nuit et jour). La clientèle généralement constituée de femmes et d’hommes se déplace des autres villages pour venir faire des achats à Zogofina. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000FCFA.qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use: Purchase of condiments, cloth, grains and firewood

loans.name: Rose's Alfa Group

texts.en:
Rose is 21 years old. She is a married with two children, ages two months and three years old. She sells vegetables. She works at her business everyday from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

Rose now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling clothes, finger millet, maize, and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sinignèsigui (Foresight) Group

texts.fr:
Sinignesigui is a group of four women from the Zogofina village of the Ségou prefecture (fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali) who are 39 years old on average. Married and mothers of at least 4 children each, they all live in traditional polygamist families with the in-laws, and generally co-spouses, their children, their husbands, and brothers and sisters. Having known each other for about a decade tied by professional, familial, and marital relationships, these women sell farm produce, seasonings, firewood, and various other items. In their desire to grow their business, the members decided to participate in Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program, which they have been doing for two years. They have already received three group loans, all of which have been properly repaid. With this new loan, they plan to buy 14 bags of peanuts, 16 loads of firewood, and a large quantity of seasonings. They stock up on seasonings at the big market in the city of Ségou (especially on market days) from people from Bamako et Sikasso, on peanuts from farmers from Konodimini, on firewood in villages with those who have wood-chopping permits (i.e., in Chola and in Bounoubougoula). The Sinignesigui group sells the items at their homes, traveling in the neighborhoods of the city of Ségou, and in neighboring village markets for cash or credit to a clientele that consists primarily of retailers and women. They hope to earn 26,000 CFA francs per month on average, which will be used to make loan payments, the rest of which will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Sinignesigui est un regroupement de quatre femmes du village de Zogofina de la préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région économique de la république du Mali) qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans. Mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants chacune, elles vivent toutes dans des familles polygames traditionnelles avec les beaux parents, généralement des coépouses, les enfants, leurs maris et des frères et soeurs. Se connaissant depuis une dizaine d’années car liées par des relations professionnelle, de parenté et de mariage, ces femmes font le commerce de produits agricoles de condiments du bois de chauffe et divers autres articles. Dans leur souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans. Elles ont bénéficié déjà de trois prêts de groupe, tous correctement remboursés. Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, 14 sacs d’arachide, 16 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et une grande quantité de condiments. Elles s’approvisionnent, en condiments au grand marché de la ville de Ségou (surtout les jours de foire) auprès des forains venant de Bamako et Sikasso, en arachide auprès des paysans producteurs de Konodimini, en bois de chauffe dans les villages avec des paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe de bois (comme à Chola et à Bounoubougoula) Les produits des membres du groupe Sinignesigui sont vendus sur place à domicile, dans les quartiers la ville de Ségou de façon ambulante et les marchés des villages voisins au comptant en détail souvent à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de revendeurs et de femmes. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 26. 000 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt investir le reste dans les affaires.

loans.use: To purchase seasonings, firewood, and peanuts

loans.name: Magreth's Bahati Group

texts.en:
Magreth is 34 years old. She is a married with one child. She owns and runs a small grocery store. She works at her business every day from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Magreth now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items to sell in her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Asha, who has a business selling vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Korotimi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Korotimi Haïdara is a 46-year-old widow living with her 2 children, her brothers and sisters, and the mothers of the paternal family in the third district of the city of Ségou (fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school for social reasons, and anxious to earn money, she ran several businesses with no success. Very enterprising and fearless in business, she decided to specialize in selling food products, notably atièké (semolina made from wild yam), which she has been doing for 20 years. Mrs. Korotimi Haïdara enjoys a good reputation and a faithfully growing clientele. After 3 group loans with a local association, which were all properly repaid, she is on her first individual loan with the credit program of microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She sells her products at the Château market in the city of Ségou on a table or in a big pile (for cash or credit) to a clientele that consists of women and men. This loan will be used to buy tons of atièké (in the Republic of the Côte d'Ivoire), tons of potatoes (in Sikasso from potato farmers) and 20 boxes of milk. She expects to earn 150,000 CFA francs, which will be used to make loan payments and to build a house for her fatherless children.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Korotimi Haïdara est une veuve âgée de 46 ans qui vit avec ses 2 enfants, ses autres frères et sœurs et les mamans dans la famille paternelle au troisième quartier de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région économique de la république du Mali). N’ayant pas eu à fréquenter l’école pour des raisons sociales, et dans le souci de s’intégrer dans la vie économique elle ména plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans réussite. Très entreprenante et courageuse dans les activités commerciales, elle décida de se spécialisesr dans le commerce des produits alimentaires notamment l’atièké (semoule à base d’igname sauvage) depuis maintenant 20 ans. Madame Korotimi Haïdara jouit d’une grande réputation et d’une clientèle fidèle en nette croissance. Après 3 prêts de groupe avec une association de son quartier tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son premier prêt indivuduel avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle vend ses marchandises au marché Château de la ville de Ségou sur une table, en tas ou dans une grande tasse (au comptant ou à crédit) à une cliente composée de femmes et d’hommes. Ce prêt sera utilisé pour l’achat, d’une tonne d’atiéké (en république de la côte d’ivoire), 1 tonne de pomme de terre (à Sikasso auprès de paysans producteurs de ce tubercule) et 20 cartons de laye. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 150 000 FCFA.qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et commencer la construction d’une maison à usage d’habitation pour ses enfants orphelins.

loans.use: To purchase semolina, milk, and potatoes

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort has been selling used clothes for the past five years in the market of Obuasi, Ghana. She relies on the income she makes from her sales to support her household by providing food and paying utility bills. Comfort is a wife and mother of four kids, who are in school. She requests the loan to enable her to inject more capital into the business to purchase more bales of used clothes. She hopes she will be able to increase her savings to support her kids' education. She is a member of the group called Progress Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en: Khalil, 49 years old, lives with his wife and 3 children in the South of Lebanon, close to Tyr. Khalil owns a small restaurant that specializes in Hummus (made of chick peas) and Foul (made of beans), which are traditional Lebanese breakfast dishes. He needs a loan of USD 1,200 for the purchase of a large inventory of chick peas and beans. This is the second time Khalil has requested a loan from Al Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner]. He successfully repaid his previous loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of a large inventory of chick peas and beans

loans.name: Lightness

texts.en:
Lightness is 27 years old. She is married with two children, ages five and one. She's owned a small general store since 2006. She works at her business from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Lightness now hopes for a loan to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Dinna's Sayuni Group

texts.en:
Dinna is married with four children between the ages of one and eleven. She has owned and run a small food shop since 2005. Everyday, she works from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Dinna now hopes for a loan to buy more items to sell in her business, like rice, sugar, oil, and salt. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Eliamani, who has a business selling clothes.

loans.use: To increase her food shop inventory.

loans.name: Korotoumou Dite Totc

texts.fr:
Mrs. Korotoumou, known as Totcho Traoré, is 60 and lives with her 4 children, her co-wife, and her husband in a polygamous family in the 3rd district of the city of Ségou (fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali). From a young age, she has been interested in earning an income with her mother, notably in selling wood coal, farm produce, fruits and vegetables, and various items. She’s been doing this for 45 years. She stocks up in the villages of Gara and Katiena and sells her fruits at home and at the Ségou market everyday. She sells the most on Mondays, Ségou’s market day. Her clientele consists mainly of women (who make fruit juices and non-alcoholic beverages), men, and children. She has been working with Soro Yiriwasao for three years. After having obtained 3 group loans with a local association, she is on her second individual loan. All of her previous loans were properly repaid. She plans to use this new loan to buy 25 bags of peanuts, 10 packets of candy, and 20 bags of zaban (a very popular exotic fruit). She foresees earning 30,000 CFA francs each month, which will be used to make loan payments and provide for her family; the rest will be invested back into her business. Her dream is to specialize (by equipping herself) in making non-alcoholic juices from exotic fruits and to build a home on her plot.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Korotoumou dite Totcho Traoré est âgée de 60 ans, et vit avec ses 4 enfants sa coépouse et son époux dans une famille polygame au troisième quartier de la ville de Ségou (quatrième économique région de la république du Mali). Dès son jeune âge elle s’est intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus à côté de sa mère notamment le commerce de charbon de bois, les produits agricoles, les fruits et légumes et divers articles. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 45 ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages de Gara et de Katiena ; et vend ses fruits à domicile et au marché de Ségou tous les jours. C’est le Lundi, jour de foire de la ville de Ségou, qu’elle réalise le plus de vente. Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes (transformatrices des fruits en jus et boissons non alcoolisées), d’hommes et d’enfants. Elle est en relation avec SORO YIRIWASAO depuis trois ans. Après avoir bouclé 3 prêts de groupe avec une association de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elle compte acheter avec ce nouveau prêt, 25 sacs d’arachides, 10 sachets de bonbons et 20 sacs de zaban (fruit exotique très prisée). Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités. Son ambition est de se spécialiser (en s’équipant) dans la transformation des fruits exotiques en jus non alcoolisée et de construire son lot à usage d’habitation.

loans.use: To purchase exotic fruits, peanuts, and candies

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 52-year-old married man and father of 6 children. He lives in a small village close to Tyre in the South of Lebanon. Hussein grows plants, vegetables and fruits in a piece of land next to his home. He needs an amount of USD 1,200 for harvesting tools. Hussein wants to expand his business further, as this will allow him to generate more revenue for his large family and therefore improve their livelihood. Hussein has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner] for the past 4 years, and he has always repaid his debts on time.

loans.use: Purchase of harvesting tools

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan, a 40-year-old married man, lives with his wife and 2 children in a small village close to Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. Hassan is an auto repairman. He needs an amount of USD 700 to cover the administrative expenses of applying for Lebanese citizenship. This is the first time that Hassan has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To pay administrative expenses of applying for Lebanese citizenship

loans.name: Djiguiya (Soutien) Group

texts.fr:
The four members of the Djiguiya Group are all married and average 36 years of age and two children, and they generally live in monogamous households in the Koko district of Kadiolo, one of the prefectures (bordering the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire and the Republic of Burkina Faso) of the Sikasso region (Republic of Mali).

They trade in foodstuffs, fabrics, soap, and various articles. Linked by ties of blood and marriage, the women of the Djiguiya Group decided six years ago to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They have benefited from twelve group loans, and all of the preceding ones have been correctly repaid.

With this loan, they intend to buy two bales of cloth to make bed sheets (to be gotten from the vendors who come from Burkina Faso), 30 kg of karité butter, 5 boxes of bath soap, 300 kg of atieké (granulated yam) in the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire, and 10 kg of fish from villages neighboring the city of Kadiola. The goods purchased in this way are sold at the grand marketplace of Kadiolo and in homes (wholesale or retail), and most of the time by cash, to an essentially female customer base.

They hope to realize a profit of 30,000 francs CFA, which will be used to help their husbands cover the family expenses and the loan interest. Each of the group members intends to become a wholesale merchant by opening a store and by diversifying their goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Les 4 membres du groupe Djiguiya sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans ans, 2 enfants et vivant en générale dans des foyers monogames dans le quartier Koko de Kadiolo l’une des préfectures (frontalières des République de la Côte d’ivoire et du Burkina Faso) de la région de Sikasso (République du Mali).

Elles font le commerce des denrées alimentaires, des tissus, des savons et d’articles divers. Liées par des relations de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe djiguiya ont décidé de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 6 ans. Elles ont bénéficié de 12 prêts de groupe et tous les précedents ont été correctement remboursés.

Avec ce prêt, elles comptent achèter 2 balles de tissus pour confectionner des draps de lit (auprès de forrains venant du Burkina Faso) , 30kg de beurre de karité, 5 cartons de savons de toilette , 300kg d’atieké en République de Cote d’Ivoire (Semoule d’ignane) et 10kg de poissons, dans les villages voisins, sur place à Kadiola. Les produits ainsi achetés sont vendus au grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo et à la maison (en gros ou en détail ) et la plupart du temps au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine.

Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 30.000 FCFA.qui sera utilisé pour aider leurs maris dans les dépenses de la famille et payer les intêrets du prêt. Chacune d’elle compte devenir une commerçante grossiste en ouvrant un magasin et en diversifiant les articles.

loans.use: To buy fish, soap, karité butter, and fabrics

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.ru:
Uguloy Q. lives in the city of Yavan. She is married and has 4 children. She has been in sales for the past 10 years. She sells children clothing and various national fabrics and shawls. She works on the Tidjorat market. Her business is successful, but most of the profit is spent on the family. She would like to increase the size of her store in order to bring in a larger variety of goods. This will allow her to attract new clients. Uguloy's business allows local inhabitants to purchase the needed goods without leaving the town. She will be able to achieve her goal of expending her business if she is given a loan for the duration of 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Курбонова Угулой проживает в городе Яван . Замужем , имеет четверых детей. Занимается торговлей. Уже 10 лет . Торгует детской одеждой и различными национальными ткакнями и платками. Работает на рынке «Тиджорат». Бизнес развивается успешно , новся прибыль уходит на содержание семьи. Теперь она хочет увеличить торговую точку для того . чтобы завезти различный ассортимент товара. Это позволит ей привлечь новых клиентов . Кроме того ее товар пользуется спросом , поэтому она помогает местным жителям приобретать необходимый товар , не выезжая за приделы кишлака. Все это она сможет реализовать только если она получит кредит сроком на 10 менсяцев.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia, age 22, is unmarried and a very hardworking trader. She enjoys selling goods, and the sale of cosmetics has been her major livelihood for the past six years. She says selling cosmetics is lucrative and her experience in the market has enabled her to gain many loyal customers. She does not have a shop at the moment, so she sells on a table at the community market. Cecilia believes that with the loan, she would have the resources to purchase more stock of cosmetics and jewelry to increase her inventory and income. She is a member of Anointed Ladies Group. Members in this group provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cosmetic products

loans.name: Zebo

texts.ru:
Zebo U. lives in the city of Yavan. She is an experienced tailor. She has been working as a tailor for the past 12 years. She is 47 years old and has 6 children. Her husband is currently away earning money for the family and therefore Zebo and her children are living on their own. She works from home. There is a large demand for her services. She tries to do her best to meet the demand. She would like to better the quality of service she provides. For this she would like to purchase a sewing machine with a serger function. For this purpose she would like to obtain a credit. She plans to return the money within an 8 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Юнусова Зебо жительница города Яван. Портниха со стажем. Работает швеей уже 12 лет. Ее возраст 47 лет и унее шестеро детей. Живет с ними одна , так как муж уехал на заработки. Работает на дому . Спрос на ее услуги очень большой. Она старается успеть обшить всех клиентов. Но Зебо очень ответственная и поэтому она хочет улучшить качество обслуживания. Для этого ей необходимо купить швейную машинку , которая делает оверлог. Поэтому она планирует получить кредит , погашать который сможет в течение 8 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Sabougnouma (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The four women of the Sabougnouma Group (meaning "Lucky Charm") average 46 years of age and four children, and they generally live in polygamous households with their husbands, co-wives, brothers, sisters, and children in the Koko district of Kadiolo, a prefecture in the Sikasso region (Republic of Mali).

They earn an income through work that essentially focuses on food products (dried, smoked, and fresh fish), fruits and vegetables (mangoes, bananas, papayas), and various goods (bread, powdered milk, sugar, etc.) They know each other by ties of community and clan. The members of the Sabougnouma Group are on their 12th loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all of the preceding ones have been correctly repaid. With this loan, they intend to buy: 10 loads of mangoes, 20 bunches of bananas, 150 kg of sugar, 7 kg of powdered milk, 300 kg of atieké (granulated yam), 15 kg of fish, and 300 loaves of bread.

They get their supplies in Kadiolo and its environs from peasant producers of fruit and vegetables. For the boutique goods, such as sugar and milk, they get their supplies in Bamako, and finally, the atieké is gotten from the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire.

These goods are resold at the grand marketplace of the city of Kadiolo and in homes (wholesale and retail) generally to a customer base made up of all social classes of the region. They hope to realize a profit of 35,000 francs CFA, which will be used to cover the loan interest, to help their husbands with family expenses, and to inject the rest into the businesses. They intend to specialize in the sale of fish and of fruits and vegetables in order to become exporters (of mangoes and fish) in the future.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Les quatre femmes du groupe Sabougnouma ont une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans, 4 enfants et vivent en générale dans les foyers polygames avec leurs maris,coépouses,frères et soeurs et enfants dans le quartier Koko de Kadiolo une préfecture de la région de sikasso( République du Mali)

Elles ont une activité économique qui tourne essentiellement autour du commerce de produits alimentaires (poissons séchés, fumés, frais), des fruits et légumes (mangues, bananes, papayes) et divers articles (pains, lait en poudre, sucre etc.). Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont à leur douzième prêt avec l’Institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Avec ce prêt, elles comptent achèter, 10 chargements de mangues, 20 regimes de banane, 150kg de sucre, 7kg de lait en poudre, 300 kg d’atieké (Semoule d’igname),15 kg de poissons et 300 miches de pains.

Elles s’approvisionnent à Kadiolo et alentours auprès de paysans producteurs de fruits et légumes. Pour les articles de boutique tel le sucre et le lait elles s’approvisionnent à Bamako. Enfin en république de côte d’voire pour l’atièké.

Ces produits sont revendus au grand marché de la ville de Kadiolo et à la maison (en gros ou en détail) généralement à une clientèle constituée de toutes les catégories sociales de la contrée. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé à payer les intérêts du prêt , aider les maris dans les dépenses de la famille et injecter le reste dans les activités. Elles comptent se spécialiser dans la vente de poissons et de fruits et légumes pour devenir dans un futur proche des exportatrices ( de mangues et poissons).

loans.use: To buy food items (fish, fruit, bread, milk, sugar, atièké) and various articles

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en: JalA., 22 years old and single, lives in a small village close to Tyre, in the South of Lebanon. JalA. is an electricA. technician for cars. His ambition and willpower led him to request a loan for the first time from A. Majmoua [Kiva’s Field Partner].  He is asking for USD 1,000 to do some maintenance on his shop and to purchase more goods such as car batteries.

loans.use: Shop maintenance and purchase of additional goods

loans.name: Rafiqa

texts.en:
Rafiqa Q. is a 47-year-old woman who breeds calves and, at the same time, sells milk to local people. She is married and has 4 children. Rafiqa started her business in 1982 in her home village in the Imishli region. As she and her husband are unemployed, her business in the only financial resource for her family.

Rafiqa would like to expand her business which can help her to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. For this purpose she has applied for US$ 1200 to purchase a milch cow for US$ 800 and two calves for US$ 200 each.

loans.use: to purchase two calves and one milch cow

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is a 37-year-old trader. She is married and blessed with four kids, who currently all attend school. Comfort says combining the demands of motherhood and business is very challenging. However, the two must be attended to simultaneously. She has traded in rice, beans, groundnuts, sugar and other food items for five years now. She is able to largely support her household through this business. She needs the loan to enable her to purchase more stock of cereals to scale up sales. She hopes the loan will enable her to double her savings to provide quality education for the kids. Comfort belongs to a group called Anointed Ladies Trust Group. The group members assist one another to repay their loans on time.

loans.use: To buy more stock of rice, beans, sugar, groundnuts, etc.

loans.name: Ferakhim

texts.en: Ferakhim F. is a 40-year-old trader whose store is in the Imishli region. He has been in business since 2000. He runs the store where he sells toothpaste, soap, shampoo, washing powder, and other bath goods. He has applied for a $1200 loan to purchase more and varied goods. Ferakhim is married and has three children.

loans.use: To purchase more and varied goods

loans.name: Hudoyberdi

texts.ru:
Hudoyberdi A. was born and lives in the city of Yavan. He has a large family. He has 6 sons all of which are , however, still small. However they too try to help the family as best as they can. Hudoyberdi works at Daewoo as a driver. His salary is not large enough to feed his large family. This is why his entire family is in business of raises cattle. Currently his business experiences a problem with animal feed. For this purpose he has decided to obtain a credit that will allow him to purchase animal feed and carry on with his business. He plans to repay the loan within a 6 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Астонов Худойберды уроженец города Яван. Имеет большую семью , где у него растут шестеро сыновей. Все они еще маленькие , но стараются помогать родителям в домашнем хозяйстве. Худойберды работает водителем в ДЭУ , но его заработная плата не настолько большая , чтобы ему хватало для того , чтобы прокормить семью. Поэтому они всей семьей занимаются животноводством. В данный момент у него возникли проблемы с комбикормом. Поэтому он решил получить кредит , не который сможет закупить корма и продолжать свой бизнес. Погасить кредит Худойберды сможет в течение 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase animal feed

loans.name: Macauley

texts.en: Macauley I. is married with four children. He is 35-years old and lives in Ubiaja, Edo State, Nigeria. He sells and repairs electrical appliances in his community, and has been in this business for 12 years. He is also a LAPO client and is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more stock to sell. He thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy I. is 51-years old married with nine children. She hails from Uromi town in Edo State. She sells gallons of oil in the local market and has been in this business since 1982. She is requesting a loan of $600 to buy more palm oil for sale.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil to sell in the market

loans.name: Boturali

texts.ru:
Boturali U. lives in the city of Yavan. He works Daewoo as a driver. He is married and has one child. He lives with and supports his parents. He has a small farm on which he raises cattle. He has found out that it is possible to obtain a credit through Kiva and decided to use this opportunity to get money to purchase a calf. This will help him increase the amount of cattle he owns and increase the size of profit brought in by his business. He plans to repay the loan within the 6 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Умаров Ботурали житель города Яван. Рботает в ДЭУ , водителем . Женат и имеет одног ребенка. Кроме того живет сродителями . Живу хорошо и дружно. Имеет небольшое хозяйство , где разводит животных. Узнал про то , что есть возможность получить кредит и решил купить бычка через получение кредита. Это поможет ему увеличить поголовье скота и получить дополнительную прибыль. А погашать кредит сможет в течение 6 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Ragim

texts.en: Ragim R. is 31 years old. His store has been in the small village of the Imishli region since 1998. He is married and has two sons. He applied for $1200 to expand his business and improve his work conditions.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy O. is married with seven children. She is 52-years old and has been in business since 1981. She sells provisions, pure water and drinks. She is from Edo State, Nigeria and is requesting a loan of $875 to start additional business which entails buying garri (ground cassava) to sell. Garri is a staple foodstuff in Nigeria.

loans.use: To start additional business selling garri (ground cassava)

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 45 years old. She is married with four children, between the ages of 17 and 23. She has been a banana seller since 2004. Everyday, she works from 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Salome now hopes for a loan to buy more bananas to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Airin

texts.en:
Airin is a married with one child, who is three years old. She sells clothing, working everyday from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Airin now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mirjana

texts.en: Mirjana is a young woman from the town of Derventa.  She is waitress at a local coffee shop, and can earn around 500 KM (375$) per month.  She recently began a hobby which she is ready to turn into a profitable business.  Mirjana has started to do ikebana, the Japanese art of flower arrangement, and wants to sell the arrangements she makes to people to use for weddings and other events.  She is requesting a loan of 600KM to get her business started.  Her salary right now is too small, so Mirjana wants earn some extra money and thinks that this business will offer a good future for her.

loans.use: To buy materials for making Japanese flower arrangements

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en: Augustine U. is 47-years old and married with four children. He lives at Ubiaja, Edo state, Nigeria. Augustine runs a rental business. People in his community come to rent chairs and canopies for their social activities. He has been in this business since 2002. Augustine is requesting a loan for $1025 to buy more chairs and canopies for his rental business. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more chairs and canopies for his business

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia I. is 40-years old and married with seven children. She lives in Ubiaja, Edo State, Nigeria. She runs a restaurant where she sells drinks and cooked foods. Felicia has been in this business since 1986. She is requesting a loan for $875 to buy a larger supply of drinks to sell in her restaurant. She says thank you.

loans.use: To supply her restaurant with more drinks

loans.name: Slobodanka

texts.en: Slobodanka is a widow from the town of Derventa. She receives a monthly pension, and also earns income by farming.  This is her 1st loan from Žene za Žene, which she is requesting in the amount of 600 KM.  She will use this to buy compost and seeds for her land.  Slobodanka will be using the seeds to grow corn, in order to have enough food to feed her cows over the winter.  She also plants vegetables and fruit trees, so will buy extra seeds for that.  Slobodanka wants to buy enough to use into the next year, as she is getting older and cannot take care of her cows all the time.  She thinks that this investment in her land will be a good move for her.

loans.use: To buy seeds and compost for farming

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is 48 years old. She is married with five children. Currently all the kids are in school. She owns and operates a grocery shop in the local market and sells items such as rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies and biscuits. She wants to use the loan to buy supplies in bulk to expand her business. Patricia hopes to make good enough income from the expanded business to enable her to provide the children with a quality education. She belongs to the community group called Humble Trust Group. The group members mutually guarantee loans through a repayment pledge and assist one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bulk food and supplies

loans.name: Marjana

texts.en: Marjana is a young  woman from the town of Derventa.  She is not married and works in a shoe factory.  She makes about 450 KM (less than 350 USD) a month through this job.  This is Marjana’s 2nd loan with Žene za Žene, which she is requesting in the amount of 800 KM.  She will use this money to order cosmetics from a wholesale retailer and then resell.  For her 1st loan, she had bought and sold cosmetics too, and is very happy with the result.  She was able to make enough to pay back her loan and  keep some for herself, and she feels confident she can do the same this time.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia is 64 years old. She is a widow with seven children. She lost her husband through a prolonged illness. The total responsibility for the kids rests on her shoulders as a single parent. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, powdered milk, etc. She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, and other items to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve sales to enable her to save more for the children's education. Emelia belongs to the community group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee loans for one another as social collateral and support one another to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of food and cosmetics

loans.name: Alimetu

texts.en: Alimetu A. is 44-years old and married with six children. She lives in Uromi, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells clothes, fabrics, bedspreads, and female foot wear and has been in this business since 2002. She is requesting a loan of $875 to buy more fabrics for her business. She expresses her gratitude to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sales

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is a widow with two kids. She runs a small business selling linen sheets and blankets in the market in Belaya Tserkov, Ukraine. Galina has been in business for over 7 years. Galina has an enterprising spirit. She is very hard-working and persevering. The success she has achieved in her business is a direct result of her efforts and commitment to her work.

Galina would like to get a loan for 5000 Grivnas to open a new vending facility and stock it with necessary merchandise. A wide selection of retail items will help her better present the benefits of her products and services to her customers. Galina tries to avoid copying the products of other market vendors. She has built a good reputation for the quality of her products and support services. We believe that her constant quest to improve her business and services will help her achieve continued success and enable her to repay this loan on time.

loans.use: To stock inventory in her new vending facility

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is a widow with two children. She is the only breadwinner in the family. Olena runs a business selling men's clothing in the local market. She has been in this business for 16 years. Olena is very decisive and determined. Her commitment and hard work has ensured a stable expansion of her business. 

Olena is asking for a loan of 5000 Grivnas to increase her current working capital. She is planning to get a bigger selection of merchandise introducing new items in her kiosk. The loan will not only help her re-supply her inventory and increase her clientele and guarantee a job for one of her employees. It will also provide for her family of three.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Happiness is 37 years old. She is a married with three children, aged 20, 14, and 6. She sells clothing. Everyday, she works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

Happiness now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes to sell in her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is 32 years old. She is married with three children. She has been a vegetable seller since 2006. Every day, she works from 1 p.m. to 12 a.m. at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $215 from her sales.

Zainabu now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana is divorced and raises her two kids alone. She runs a small business selling men's outerwear in the central city market. Svitlana has been in this trade for 12 years. Presently, she has about $6000 invested in inventory. Her income is about $1300. 

Svitlana's diligent, hard work has helped her succeed in business and helps maintain her loyal clientele. Svitlana would like to receive a loan for 5000 Grivnas to serve as working capital in her business. Financial assistance will help her purchase an assortment of high-quality, durable, and comfortable outerwear. It will help Svitlana's business grow, especially for the upcoming fall season.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is divorced and has one child. Larisa is the only breadwinner in the family. She used some of her savings to start small business selling clothing and footwear.
