Lupe de 29 años, es madre de 3 hijos que cursan estudios primarios, vive con su esposo Esaú, quien se dedica a la venta de combustible, y es quien la apoya en sus objetivos trazados. Lupe se dedica al negocio la venta de fruta en una pequeña ramada en su vivienda, desde hace ya 2 años, ella vende por horas ya que son productos que se terminan rápido. Por su buena atención y amabilidad cuenta con mucha clientela, y siempre tiene sus productos buenos y frescos. Le gusta mucho su trabajo, porque así, conoce a mucha gente. Lo difícil para ella, es no contar con un local apropiado para su negocio. Trabaja para la educación de sus hijos y solventar algunos gastos familiares. Quiere invertir el dinero que solicita en la construcción de un kiosco, y surtirse con más producto.

loans.use: Build a kiosk for fruit business.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira is 58 years old and belongs to the “Señor del Cautivo II” community bank. She lives with her husband and her three children. She says her major problem is not having a fixed store location.

One of her objectives is to have a store selling clothing and other items, as well as being able to travel places with her husband who is already retired.

With this loan of 1,700 Soles, which will be repaid in 8 payments, she will buy leather jackets from the Villa el Salvador factory in Lima in order to sell them in the streets of her neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Elvira tiene 58 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor del Cautivo II”, vive con su esposo y 3 hijos. Dice que su mayor dificultad es ser ambulante, aunque ya se ha acostumbrado a ello, es una situación difícil que afronta desde hace 30 años. Uno de sus objetivos es tener una tiendita, con venta de ropas y otros artículos y poder viajar con su esposo ya jubilado a otros lugares a pasear. Con el préstamo de S/ 1,700 soles, el cual será pagado en 8 cuotas, comprará casacas de cuero de la fabrica de Villa el Salvador en Lima para poder venderlas en las calles de su localidad de forma ambulante.

loans.use: Purchase of leather jackets

loans.name: Reynalda

texts.es:
Seven years ago, Reynalda's daughter wanted to study cosmetology, when she was only 13. Reynalda took her to her classes every day, and this is how both mother and daughter learned this skill.

Six years ago, Reynalda decided to start a small salon in her home. She works every day, and her neighbors and friends are familiar with her work. Reynalda also sells nutritional products called Omnilife. She offers them in a display case located in her salon.

She has used the loans she has received to furnish her salon and to purchase supplies for her work.

Reynalda also has plans to sell candy in a cart outside of her house. She would like to have another salon.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Hace 7 años, la hija de Reynalda quiso estudiar cosmetología teniendo tan solo 13 años. Por ello, Reynalda la llevaba todos los días a sus clases. Fue así que tanto la hija como la madre aprendieron este oficio.

De esta manera, hace 6 años, Reynalda decidió instalar una peluquería en su casa. Ella trabaja todo el día y ya sus vecinos y amigos la conocen. Asimismo, Reynalda vende productos nutricionales Onmilife. Ella los ofrece en una vitrina colocada en su peluquería.

Los préstamos recibidos los ha utilizado en amoblar su peluquería y para comprar sus materiales de trabajo.

Reynalda también tiene planes de vender golosinas en una carreta afuera de su casa. A ella le gustaría tener otra peluquería.

loans.use: To furnish her salon and to purchase supplies for her work

loans.name: Luci

texts.es:
Luci, 41, is the mother of 3 school-aged children who are the inspiration behind her dreams for getting ahead. She lives with her husband, Carlos, who works independently. Luci's business is selling chickens and other animals. She gets up very early each day to go to the local port so that she can buy different animals from the breeders there. She takes them to resell to her customers who are, for the most part, cooks in the market. She's been operating the business for 4 years now. She works for her daily expenses and to educate her children who are her reason for being. She wants to build a corral for the animals that she buys so that she can more easily transfer them to market. That's the reason for her loan application.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Luci tiene 41 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos que están estudiando y son su mayor inspiración para lograr lo que desea. Vive junto a su esposo Carlos quien trabaja independientemente. La venta de gallinas y otros animales es la actividad diaria que tiene Luci, se levanta muy temprano para ir al puerto, comprar a los ganaderos los diferentes animales que traen y luego llevarlos a revender a sus clientes, que son en su mayoría, cocineras de los mercados. Esta actividad la viene realizando desde hace ya 4 años. Trabaja para sus gastos diarios y la educación de sus hijos quienes son su razón de ser. Quiere mandar a construir un corralón para los animales que compra y tener mayor facilidad para llevarlos a vender, este es el motivo por el cual solicita este préstamo.

loans.use: Build a corral for livestock business.

loans.name: Giovanny Marizela

texts.es:
Opening a spare auto parts store is the goal of Giovanny, 38 years old, who has the help of her husband who is also a merchant. She has been selling sacs as a traveling saleswoman in Huaraz for almost 11 years.

With four children and a house being built, she struggles with the evictions that the municipality enforces, so she carries her sacs on the shoulder and walking she delivers her sacs on the market days in Huaraz.

She belongs to the “Señor del Cautivo II” community bank. With this loan of 800 Soles, which will be repaid in 6 payments, she will invest in her business buying 200 sacs and also merchandise for her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Abrir una tienda de tornos y repuestos de Autos es la meta de Giovanny de 38 años, quien tiene la ayuda de su esposo que también es comerciante, ella vende por casi 11 años costales de manera ambulatoria en las calles de Huaraz.

Con cuatro hijos y una casa en construcción, día a día, ella lucha con los desalojos que les hacen los municipales, así que carga sus costales al hombro y caminando va repartiendo sus costales en los días de feria en Huaraz.

Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor del Cautivo II”. Con este préstamo de S/. 800 soles, el cual pagará en 6 cuotas, implementará su negocio, comprará dos cientos de costales y también mercadería para su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase of sacs at wholesale prices

loans.name: Jenny Margoth

texts.es:
Jenny is 40 years old and is the mother of 3 marvelous children that are studying for professional careers in a well-recognized university. Jenny is a primary school teacher by profession and in her husband Jorge she has her greatest support. She earns a living by raising and selling poultry, as well as raising cockfighters which she either rents or sells. She has been doing this work for 10 years. She begins selling the poultry chickens every 25 days, while the cockfighters are major competitors in coliseums. Both the chickens and cockfighters generate good income. She likes this work very much because she socializes and gets to know more about raising the birds. The most difficult thing for her is that she does not have an adequate shed and pens for her birds, so that she keeps all of them in her house. Jenny wants to build a shed, buy chicks and feed, and also build an adequate pen for her cockfighters.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer.

Jenny tiene 40 años, es madre de 3 hijos maravillosos que estudian carreras profesionales en una universidad muy reconocida. Jenny es de profesión profesora de educación primaria y tiene a su esposo Jorge como su mayor apoyo. Se dedica a la crianza y venta de pollos de granja, también cría gallos de pelea, los mismos que alquila o vende. Realiza esta labor desde hace 10 años. A sus pollos de granja los empieza a vender cada 25 días, mientras que sus gallos de pelea son grandes competidores en los coliseos; ambos le generan bueno ingresos. Le gusta mucho esta actividad porque socializa y conoce más acerca de la crianza de pollos. Lo más difícil para ella, es no contar con un galpón adecuado y corrales para sus gallos ya que todo lo tiene dentro de su casa. Jenny quiere mandar a construir un galpón, comprar pollos bebes y alimento, además de construir un corral adecuado para sus gallos de pelea.

loans.use: Construction of suitable pens for raising her chickens and fighting cocks

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es:
Florencia has several businesses. She sells chica de jora (a corn-based drink) every day in her home. However, two years ago Florencia was very ill and a friend recommended some Chinese medicines. She tried them and they worked very well which is why now she sells them and shares information about them. Also, Florencia sells homemade desserts outside her home every afternoon. Before, she distributed bread, but she quit doing that because she was having to walk a great deal.

She has used the loans that she has requested to invest in the businesses that she has to increase business capital. Florence would like to be able to work full time selling and promoting the Chinese medicinal products that she offers.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Florencia tiene varios negocios. Ella vende chicha de jora (bebida a base de maíz) todos los días en su casa. Sin embargo, hace 2 años Florencia estuvo muy enferma, por lo que un amigo le recomendó unas medicinas chinas. Ella las probó y le funcionó muy bien, por lo que ahora se dedica a venderlas y hacerlas conocidas. Igualmente, Florencia vende postres caseros afuera de su casa, todas las tardes. Antes, ella repartía pan, pero dejó esta actividad debido a que tenía que caminar mucho. Los préstamos solicitados los ha utilizado para invertir en los negocios que tiene y para hacerse de un capital. A Florencia le gustaría poder dedicarse a tiempo completo a las ventas y promoción de los productos medicinales chinos que ofrece.

loans.use: Invest in different businesses to increase business capital.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana, 64 years old, stills struggles day to day to improve her business. After experimenting with different activities she decided to remain with her spice stores, since it seems more peaceful to her and she earns 70 soles a week.

The experience she lived with her husband, from whom she later separated, was enough for her to remain single and dedicate herself to raising her four children that are now adults. With the loan of 1,700 soles, that Movimiento Manuela Ramos will proviD. to her and will be repaid in 6 payments, she will buy sacs of ají panca (red chili pepper), yellow chili pepper, dried chili pepper, black pepper and cumin at wholesale prices.

Juana belongs to the “Señor del Cautivo II” community bank, and feels proud of having been able to raise her four children with her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Juana D. 64 años, aún lucha para mejorar día a día su negocios, después D. experimentar diferentes actividades decidió quedarse con las especerías, ya que le parece mas tranquilo y donD. gana 70 soles semanales.

La experiencia vivida con su esposo, D. quien luego se separó, le fue suficiente para que se quedará soltera y dedicarse a criar a sus cuatro hijos que ahora son mayores D. edad. Con el préstamo D. S/. 1,700 soles, que le otorgará el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, el cual pagará en 6 cuotas, comprará sacos D. ají panca, amarillo, seco, pimienta y comino al por mayor, los cuales molerá con sus máquinas.

Ella que pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor del Cautivo II”,se siente orgullosa D. haber podido criar a sus cuatro hijos con su propio negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients at wholesale prices

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is an example of a successful businesswoman. For the past 15 years, she has imported garlic from the mountains in order to resell them at a profit in different markets in Lima. She imports tons of garlic and she processes them in her house. Many times her house was too small in order to store the huge quantities of this product.

Also, she has a business to rent cell phones in order to make calls on the road. She has 4 hired girls for the entire area of her district dedicated to this work.

She also has under her ownership three sweets kiosks that work in various neighborhoods in Lima. Finally, Carmen also sells lunches and snacks.

The loans that she has asked for her has used to buy the cell phones for her calling business. She has plans to continue growing these businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Carmen es un ejemplo de empresaria exitosa. Desde hace 15 años, ella trae ajos de la sierra para repartirlos por mayor a diferentes mercados de lima. Ella trae los ajos por toneladas y los procesa en su casa. Muchas veces su casa queda pequeña para albergar las grandes cantidades de este producto.

Asimismo, ella tiene un negocio de alquiler de celulares para hacer llamadas al paso. Tiene 4 chicas repartidas por toda la zona de su distrito dedicadas a este trabajo.

También tiene bajo su poder 3 quioscos de golosinas que trabajan en diversas zonas de Lima. Por último, Carmen también vende almuerzos y los reparte.

Los préstamos que ha solicitado los ha utilizado en la compra de los celulares para su negocio de llamadas. Ella tiene planes de seguir aumentando sus negocios.

loans.use: To buy cell phones that she needs for her calling business.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda has sold breakfast outside of her mother's house for four years. Every day she starts selling at 6:30 a.m. until 9:00 a.m. In the afternoons, she sells flavored drinks that she delivers to her neighbors. In the summer, she offers iced beverages.

She has invested the loans she has received in the purchase of utensils that she needs to make the breakfast she sells.

Hilda would like to sell food in the afternoons as well.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Hilda vende desayunos afuera de la casa de su mamá desde hace 4 años. Todos los días empieza a vender desde las 6.30 hasta las 9 de la mañana. Por las tardes vende emolientes que reparte a sus vecinos. En el verano ofrece refrescos helados.

Los préstamos que ha recibido los ha invertido en la compra de los utensilios que necesita para hacer sus desayunos.

A Hilda le gustaría vender comida en las tardes.

loans.use: To purchase the utensils she needs to make the breakfast she sells

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
For two years, Hilda has been dedicated to selling clothing and general merchandise by taking orders. She used to work as an employee in a flower shop. This is how Hilda started to deliver her flower arrangements that her neighbors ordered from her. They started to ask her for other products, and this is why she was motivated to dedicate herself to selling by taking orders.

She has used the loans she has requested to purchase the products that her customers order from her.

Hilda would like to have a stand in a market to sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Desde hace 2 años, Hilda se dedica a la venta de ropa y productos en general por pedidos. Antes ella trabajaba como empleada en una tienda de arreglos florales. Fue así que Hilda llevaba a repartir por su casa los arreglos que le encargaban sus vecinos. Ellos le empezaron a pedir otros productos y de esta manera se animó a dedicarse a la venta por pedidos.

Los préstamos que ha solicitado los ha utilizado en la compra de los productos que le piden.

Hilda quisiera tener un puesto en el mercado y vender ropa.

loans.use: To purchase the products she sells by taking orders

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
For the past twenty years, Graciela cooked in a popular restaurant that ran from her house. One part of the expense of this restaurant demand is subsidized by the State, and the other part she supplies. She works from 8:30 in the morning until 1:00 in the afternoon.

Before, Graciela sold fruit in an open air market, but she was laid off and had to look for new opportunities. This was how she began to weave handmade sweaters. She weaves 1 sweater per week. Her clients were her family and friends.

The loans that she has gotten she has used to buy the food that she needs in the kitchen for the wool that she uses in the sweaters that she makes.

Graciela has planned to stop cooking in the popular restaurant and to dedicate herself completely to weaving. Also she wants to sell soft drinks in the summer.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Desde hace 20 años, Graciela cocina en el comedor popular que funciona en su casa. Una parte del gasto que este comedor demanda es subsidiada por el Estado, y otra parte ella lo invierte. Ella trabaja desde las 8.30 de la mañana hasta la 1 de la tarde.

Graciela antes vendía fruta como ambulante, pero a raíz de un desalojo, tuvo que buscar nuevas oportunidades. Fue así que ella también empezó a tejer chompas a mano. Teje 1 chompa a la semana. Sus clientes son sus familiares y amistades.

Los préstamos que ha pedido los ha utilizado en la compra de los víveres que necesita en el comedor y para la lana que utiliza en las chompas que teje.

Graciela tiene planeado dejar de cocinar en el comedor popular y dedicarse solo al tejido. También quiere vender refrescos en el verano.

loans.use: To buy food for a restaurant and for wool to use in making sweaters.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
For the past two years, Magdalena has dedicated herself in making clothing. Her husband works for a tailoring business, and this was how she learned the work. Later her children bought machines, and with them, Magdalena began to make clothing. Now she has a small factory in her house. She provides seamstress services to businesses of jeans and dress coats. She even has employees.

Before, Magdalena had a convenience store in her own location at the side of her house, but later she closed it and how she has a rented location.

The loans that she has asked for she has used to buy thread, sewing materials, and to pay the employees that she has hired.

Magdalena would like to increase her business and to have another location in the center of Lima.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Desde hace 2 años, Magdalena se dedica a la confección de ropa. Su esposo trabaja para una empresa de costura, fue así que ella aprendió el oficio. Luego sus hijos compraron las máquinas y con ellos, Magdalena empezó a confeccionar ropa. Ahora tiene un pequeño taller en su casa. Ella hace servicios de costura a empresas de jeans y casacas. Cuenta con ayudantes.

Antes, Magdalena tenía una tienda de abarrotes en un local propio al costado de su casa, pero luego lo cerró y ahora lo tiene alquilado.

Los préstamos que ha solicitado los ha utilizado en la compra de hilos, material de costura y pagar al personal que tiene contratado.

Magdalena quisiera ampliar su negocio e instalar otro taller en el centro de Lima.

loans.use: To buy the thread, sewing materials, and to pay employees

loans.name: Karina

texts.es:
Karina's mother-in-law has a sewing shop, and two years ago, she decided to work with her in this business. Before, Karina was an employee in a factory that made jeans. This is where she learned to sew.

She has invested the loans she has received in the purchase of thread and in paying the personnel that works in her mother-in-law's sewing shop.

Karina would like to purchase more machines to put in the shop that she shares with her mother-in-law.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La suegra de Karina tiene un taller de confecciones, por lo que hace 2 años ella decidió incursionar también en este negocio, y trabajar conjuntamente con su suegra. Antes, Karina era empleada en un taller de confección de jeans. Fue allí donde aprendió a coser.

Los préstamos que ha recibido los ha invertido en la compra de hilos y para pagar al personal que trabaja en el taller de confección de su suegra.

A Karina le gustaría comprar más máquinas e implementar el taller que comparte con su suegra.

loans.use: To purchase the thread she needs to sew and to pay the personnel that works in her mother-in-law's sewing shop

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María has worked for two years as a domestic employee. One year ago, María started selling soft drinks and fruit lollipops in her house. She also makes tamales on the weekends, which she delivers to her neighbors and friends. Recently, she has started to sell clothing.

She has used the loans she has received to purchase the ingredients she needs to make tamales.

María would like to finish constructing her house and to open a store.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

María ha trabajado por dos años como empleada doméstica. Sin embargo, desde hace 1 año, María vende gaseosas y chupetes de frutas en su casa. Asimismo, ella también hace tamales los fines de semana, los cuales reparte a sus vecinos y amistades. Últimamente ha empezado a vender ropa por pedidos.

Los préstamos que ha recibido los ha utilizado en la compra de los ingredientes que necesita para hacer sus tamales.

A María le gustaría terminar de construir su casa y poner una tienda.

loans.use: To purchase the ingredients she needs to make tamales

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana used to sell thread in an open air market. One day she was laid off and she saw the need to look for new work. A friend of hers encouraged her to try the business of selling cosmetics by catalog. Now Susana goes out every day to offer her products to neighbors and friends.

She has used the loans she has already received to pay for advance orders of cosmetics and to have stock in her house.

Susana would like to have a clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Susana vendía hilos de forma ambulatoria. Un día fue desalojada y se vio en la necesidad de buscar un nuevo trabajo. Una amiga la animó a incursionar en el negocio de las ventas de cosméticos por catálogo. Ahora Susana sale todos los días a ofrecer sus productos a vecinos y amistades. Los préstamos que ha recibido los ha utilizado en pagar por adelantado los cosméticos que vende y para tener un stock en su casa. A Susana le gustaría tener una tienda de ropa.

loans.use: To pay for advance orders of the cosmetics that she sells and to have a stock of cosmetics in her house.

loans.name: Domitila

texts.es:
For the past 4 years, Domitila has woven artisanal bracelets by hand. Previously she provided weaving services for other individuals, but now she sells directly to the wholesalers. She weaves about 1000 bracelets/necklaces per week. Also, Domitila and her spouse have a stall in a commercial center where she sells jeans. The loans that she has received she has used to buy the threads to weave the bracelets, and for her stock of jeans. Domitilia would like to have another stall of children’s clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Desde hace 4 años, Domitila teje pulseras artesanales a mano. Antes hacía servicio de tejido para otras personas, pero ahora las vende directamente a los mayoristas. Teje alrededor de 1000 pulseras a la semana. También, Domitila tiene con su esposo un puesto en un centro comercial donde vende jeans. Los préstamos que ha recibido los ha utilizado en la compra de los hilos para tejer las pulseras, y para el stock de jeans. A Domitila le gustaría tener otro puesto de ropa para niños.

loans.use: To buy the thread she needs to make sweaters, and to buy jeans for her shop.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
For the past three years, María has woven artisanal bracelets. She provides weaving services to other people. In a week she does 100 bracelets. At the same time, María sells desserts outside of the house of her mother-in-law, one time per week. Finally, María rents out her garage and keeps 2 cars there every day. At the moment, she is enlarging her garage in order to keep two more cars. She has used her previous loans to enlarge her garage. María would like to be able to fix her garage to give it a door and a roof of strong material.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky and John Glassmire, Kiva Volunteers.

Desde hace 3 años, María teje pulseras artesanales. Ella hace servicios de tejido a otras personas. A la semana hace 100 pulseras. Igualmente, María vende postres afuera de la casa de sus suegra, una vez por semana. Por último, María alquila su cochera y guarda 2 autos todos los días. Actualmente, está ampliando su cochera para poder guardar 2 autos más. Los préstamos que ha utilizado le han servido para ampliar su cochera. A María le gustaría poder arreglar su cochera colocándole una puerta y techo de material resistente.

loans.use: To enlarge María's garage so she can rent out more car spaces

loans.name: Edelvina Isolina

texts.es:
Edelvina is 37 years of age and currently lives with her five children and her husband.

More than half a year ago, Edelvina and her husband opened up a shop where they make musical instruments in an artisanal style. On a daily basis they make guitars and harps. Edelvina joins her husband in the daily work of the shop. She is in charge of putting on the finish, like varnish. In this way, she and her husband make a stupendous pair. After production, they sell their products at the main market in their town. This business is enjoyable for Edelvina and, above all, for her husband who had the brilliant idea of starting this shop and to apply all he learned since he was a child.

The goal of these efforts is to see their family and their children with a better quality of life.

They ask for a loan of 300 soles ($125) with which they will buy wood and materials for the making of the instruments. They would like see their shop improving all of the time and not only make instruments but also furniture and do metalwork.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Edelvina tiene 37 años de edad y en la actualidad vive con sus 5 hijos y su esposo.

Hace más de medio año, Edelvina y su esposo instalaron un taller para la fabricación de instrumentos musicales de manera artesanal, diariamente fabrican guitarras y arpas, Edelvina acompaña diariamente a su esposo en los trabajos requeridos en el taller, ella se encarga de darle el acabado final, como el barnizado. De esta manera ella y su esposo hacen una dupla estupenda, luego de su elaboración los venden en el mercado principal de su localidad. Esta actividad es disfrutada por Edelvina, y sobre todo por su esposo, quien tuvo la brillante idea de implementar este taller y aplicar lo que aprendió desde su niñez.

El motivo de su esfuerzo es para ver a su familia y a sus hijos con una mejor calidad de vida.

Solicitan un préstamo de 300 soles, con el cual comprará madera y materiales para la elaboración de los instrumentos, ellos quieren ver su taller cada vez mejor y no solo fabricar instrumentos, sino también muebles y realizar carpintería metálica.

loans.use: Purchase of Materials for the Making of Musical Instruments.

loans.name: Joel Elvis

texts.es:
Joel is 31 years of age, is the father of the family and lives with his wife and two small children.

He has made coffins for ten years, a trade he learned from his father-in-law and that today is the economic support for his home. He has a shop in his home that he works in all day. He makes two coffins per week and later sells them to funeral companies and in this way generates income. Up to now, he has been very satisfied because this has allowed him to support his family as well as to enjoy his work on a daily basis. For him, his greatest difficulty is the amount of capital which many times is insufficient for growth, but he is working on it so that he can expand his horizons.

The reasons for his efforts are his family and the responsibility he has to care for it as a good father and provider.

Joel asks for a loan because he wants to be able to outfit his shop with wood, paint and varnish which are all indispensable supplies for his work. With the loan, he will be able to increase the capital of his work since it is his intention to be able to have his own funeral services business.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Joel tiene 31 años, es padre de familia, vive con su esposa y sus 2 hijos pequeños.

Se dedica a la fabricación de ataúdes o cajones mortuorios desde hace 10 años, por medio de su suegro que le enseñó este oficio, y que hoy es el soporte económico de su hogar. Tiene su taller en su propia casa, al que le dedica todo el día, realiza 2 ataúdes por semana y luego los vende a las empresas funerarias, de esta manera se genera ingresos, hasta el momento le a traído muchas satisfacciones porque le permite sostener a su familia, además de que disfruta diariamente de su trabajo, para él su mayor dificultad es la cantidad de capital, muchas veces es insuficiente para crecer, pero está trabajando en ello para poder expandir sus horizontes.

La razón de su esfuerzo es su familia y la responsabilidad que tiene de cuidar de ella, como buen padre sustentador.

Joel solicita un préstamo porque desea poder implementar su taller con madera, pintura y barniz, que son insumos indispensables para su trabajo, con ello podrá acrecentar su capital de trabajo, ya que su mira es poder tener su propia empresa funeraria.

loans.use: Purchase of Raw Material for the Making of his Coffins.

loans.name: Emma María

texts.es:
Doña Emma is 51 years old. Currently, she lives with two of her three children and her husband.

She has had her pharmacy for three years. This business was a gift from her oldest daughter. Emma brings her knowledge of health sciences to advise her customers on medicines as she is a nurse by profession. Attending to her pharmacy is her greatest satisfaction because she gets to practice her profession and offers only safe medicines brought directly from authorized pharmaceutical laboratories. Sometimes, she has to help her clients who come to her at any hour of the day or night, but, for Emma, this is very flattering.

Emma focuses on the service in her pharmacy because, in the future, she wants to be able to establish many branches and leave them to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Emma tiene 51 años, actualmente vive con 2 de sus 3 hijos y su esposo.

Ella tiene su botica desde hace 3 años, este negocio fue un obsequio de su hija mayor. Emma vuelca todos sus conocimientos de las ciencias de la salud para orientar a sus clientes sobre medicamentos ya que ella es enfermera de profesión. Atender su botica es su mejor satisfacción porque ejerce su profesión, y solo ofrece medicamentos seguros que trae directamente de los laboratorios farmacéuticos autorizados. A veces debe atender a sus clientes que acuden a ella a cualquier hora del día y la noche, pero para Emma es muy halagador.

Emma se esfuerza en la atención de su botica porque desea a futuro poder establecer varias sucursales y dejarles en herencia a sus hijos.

loans.use: Invest in her pharmacy and add to her shop some bazaar-type items

loans.name: Marco Antonio

texts.es:
Marco is 35 years of age and lives with his wife and two children. He has made coffins since childhood and, during those years, his father taught him the trade he inherited and that, today, allows him to support his family. Marco has made his coffins for 15 years and always is dedicated to making new models and better paints. He gives all of his time to this business. In winter, he usually reduces his wood supply because he has to plan ahead and buy all of his materials in advance. The goal of his efforts is to have something better for his family.

Marco asks for a loan that he will invest responsibly in wood to avoid the difficulties of the season. His goal is to have a large full-service funeral parlor.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

Marco tiene 35 años y vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos. Desde su niñez se ha dedicado a la fabricación de ataúdes y fue enseñado durante todos estos años por su padre que le heredó este oficio, que hoy en día le permite sostener a su familia. Marco viene fabricando sus ataúdes desde hace 15 años y siempre esta al pendiente en la elaboración de nuevos modelos y mejores pinturas, a este negocio le se dedica tiempo completo, en época de invierno suele bajar el abastecimiento de madera por la cual Marco tiene que anticiparse y comprar todos sus insumos por adelantado. El motivo de su esfuerzo es porque desea tener algo mejor para su familia.

Marco solicita un crédito que invertirá responsablemente en implementarse de madera y evitar las dificultades de la temporada, su meta es tener una gran funeraria que ofrezca todos los servicios.

loans.use: The Purchase of Raw Material for the Making of his Coffins

loans.name: Kamila

texts.en: Kamila (her brother is pictured) is 51 years old and is the mother of three children. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Lachin region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan.  Eight years ago Kamila and her brother started a food market business. They need a loan of  $1200 to buy more food items to help improve their business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim has been in this business for 5 years. He transports agricultural produce with his car. He is married and has 2 children. Ibrahim is is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Agdam region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He has settled in Khirdalan town. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Fuzula

texts.en:
Fuzula is a mother of five children (pictured is one of her sons) She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Zangilan region in Azerbaijan and has settled in the Absheron region. Her children help her out in the general food store business.
She has been in this business for threeyears. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy more food items to help improve her business.

loans.use: to buy the foodstuffs

loans.name: Ahadi

texts.en:
Ahadi is 20 years old. She is single. She has been rearing chicken since 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Ahadi now hopes for a loan to buy more chickens for her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 39 years old. She is a married with 7 children between 9 and 20. She has owned a small cafe since 2003. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Mary now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Dorothea's Chapakazi Group

texts.en:
Dorothea is married with 5 children between 14 and 25 years old. She has been a local beer seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

Dorothea now seeks a loan to buy a cow in order to get milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses that include a bar, vegetable and maize sales, charcoal sales and a grocery store.

loans.use: To buy a cow.

loans.name: Lidya

texts.en:
Lydya is married with 1 child, aged 18. She is a milk seller. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

Lydia now hopes for a loan to buy more milk for her business.

loans.use: To buy more milk for her business.

loans.name: Fezy

texts.en: Fezy (his wife is pictured) is 28, married, and has two children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Gubadli region in Azerbaijan, and is settled in the Absheron region. The F.'s family started a general food business ten years ago. Now his family needs a loan of $1200 to buy more food items to help improve their business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Magreth's Titanic Group

texts.en:
Magreth is 32 years old. She is married with two children aged 14 and 7. She has been a bites seller since 2005 and can earn a monthly profit of about $700 from her sales.

Magreth now hopes for a loan to buy more bite for her business. She will share this loan with her group member Blandina, who has a business dealing with charcoal and oil sales.

loans.use: To buy more bites items for her business.

loans.name: Alfa Na Omega Group

texts.en:
Nash is 38 years old. She is married with four children ages 20, 17, 15 and 8. She has owned a small general store since 1996. Every day she works from 6am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $825 from her sales.

Nash now hopes for a loan to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her group members Asha and Marsela, who have businesses dealing with food and maize sales.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Lilian's Mpaji Mungu Group

texts.en:
Lilian is married with two children aged seven and four. She has been a charcoal seller since 2007. Every day she works from 8am to 6pm and earns a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Lilian now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal inventory for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who have businesses selling cassava, fish and charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal inventory.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 41 years old and has settled in the town of Khirdalan.  He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Kalbadjar region in Azerbaijan. He is married and has two children. He began his general store business 16 years ago. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy more goods to help improve his business.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Evaline

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Evaline K. from Dar es Salaam. She is a wonderful woman who has devoted her career to the care and education of the Tanzanian young. Evaline runs a nursery school in Dar, which she established in 2002. With two other employees, Evaline nurtures young Tanzanian boys and girls every day of the week during the school year and prepares them to enter elementary school. We could really use more dedicated people like her!

Evaline’s school earns her approximately US$ 200 in monthly profits. She is requesting US$ 525 from Kiva for capital to renovate her school, specifically the classrooms, and employ more teachers to deal with the nursery school's growing needs.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To renovate her nursery school and to employ additional teachers

loans.name: Agness's Confidence Group

texts.en:
Agness is 45 years old. She is married with five children between the ages of 8 and 21. She has been a rice seller since 2008. Every day she works from 9am to 7pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $550 from her sales.

Agness has previously taken out a loan to expand her business. She is applying for a second loan to purchase more rice inventory. She will share this loan with her group member Magreth, who has a business dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more rice for her business.

loans.name: Domina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-one-year-old Domina A. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children under the age of five. Domina runs a stationery store in the Tabata district of Dar, which she established in 2006. The foresight and insight of people who have never received any training in business management, never ceases to amaze me. Stationary sales is a business where such wisdom is demonstrated, with most sellers placing their shops, stalls, tables or bodies strategically near to post offices, banks, schools and universities.

Domina is no exception! Her well-situated store earns her US$ 200 in monthly profits. Domina further demonstrates her business acumen through the intended use of her loan. She is requesting $875 to buy a photocopier which she will then allow her customers to use for a fee. I’m confident that Domina will be able to obtain a good return on her investment before the end of her loan term.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy a photocopier for her stationery store

loans.name: Zainabu's Wisdom Group

texts.en:
Zainabu is 32 years old. She is married with five children between the ages of four and fifteen. She has been selling fish and cassava since 2006. Every day she works from 11am to 9pm and earns a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Zainabu now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and cassava for her business. She will share this loan with her group member Aisha, who has a business selling tomatoes.

loans.use: To buy more fish and cassava for her business.

loans.name: Wema

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Wema is a twenty-nine-year-old woman from Dar es Salaam. As she is divorced, she is solely responsible for supporting her nine-year-old son, Ally. She is a new entrepreneur who established a business selling traditional African cloth called batik only six months ago. Tanzanian women buy her cloth to wear as vitenge, which is the traditional outfit worn by local women.

Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Most often, it is a multicolored, dark wax print on a lighter background. Kitenge is also a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

Wema currently earns about US$ 60 per month from the sale of her cloth. She is requesting a loan of US$ 275 to purchase for her store additional stocks of cloth in bulk, which she will then retail for a profit. She is hopeful that this loan will enable her to increase the quantity and stock of her business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase supplies of cloth in bulk for her store

loans.name: Olimpya's Ngorongoro Group

texts.en:
Olimpya is married with two children aged ten and five; she also cares for a 15-year-old child. She became a food seller in 2004. Every day she works from 8am to 6pm and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Olimpya now hopes for a loan to buy more cosmetics inventory for her business. She will share this loan with her group member Elizabeth, who also has a business dealing in clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics items for her business.

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Zubeda is a forty-five-year-old married woman from Dar es Salaam with two children. In 2004, she established her business of selling batik cloth, which she now runs with two employees.

Batik is a type of traditional African cloth dyed in vibrant colors and it typically depicts a variety of themes and motifs. Batik cloth is in great demand with both local women and tourists who buy it to fashion outfits from.

Zubeda’s store is very successful and earns her approximately US$ 500 in profits. She is requesting a loan of US$ 775 in order to purchase additional raw materials such as cloth and dyes to enable her to make batik cloth. In the future, Zubeda aspires to be successful enough to open another location of her shop.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her business in bulk

loans.name: Tumaini's Bidii Group

texts.en:
Tumaini is 30 years old. She is married with a five-year-old child. She has been a shoe seller since 2006, and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Tumaini now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who have businesses dealing with food sales, shoe and clothing sales, and bites sales.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for her business.

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar is 51 years old,  is married, and has two children.  He is settled in the town of Khirdalan. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Kalbadjar region in Azerbaijan. Four years ago he started a business selling cisterns. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy the materials for making  more cisterns to help improve his business.

loans.use: to buy the materials for making the cisterns

loans.name: Anjelina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Angelina is a forty-year-old married woman from Dar es Salaam with two children. She is an extremely enterprising woman who has crafted a successful business from selling vinyagos to tourists. A vinyago is a beautiful hand-crafted statue made from wood by members of the Makonde tribe, who hail from southeastern Tanzania.

Woodcarving is an important part of Makonde life, both in ancestor worship and in their own myth of creation. These statues have three main themes: traditional masks, motifs of female ancestor worship, as well as more abstract modern themes.

Anjelina buys these statues in bulk from the Makonde and retails them in Dar at a profit; her business earns her about US$ 200 in monthly profits. She is requesting a loan of US$ 625 as more capital to buy an increased supply of these traditional articrafts.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy traditional Tanzanian statues in bulk and retail them to tourists as souvenirs

loans.name: Marietha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Marietha is a thirty-five-year-old married mother from Dar es Salaam. She has four children between the ages of eight and eighteen. Marietha runs a small store from which she sells essential grocery items in Dar es Salaam.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Marietha started her stall in 2006 and she has been earning monthly profits of US$ 100 from it since. She is requesting a loan of US$ 275 in order to purchase additional stocks of vegetables in bulk. She intends to retail these for a profit and hopefully increase the quantity and range of her products in the future.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Bertha's Upendo Group

texts.en:
Bertha is 36 years old. She is married with 5 children between the ages of three and eighteen. She has owned a small shop since 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 9pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Bertha now hopes for a loan to buy more products like rice and sugar for her business. She will share this loan with her group members Glory and Emmy, who also have businesses dealing with vegetable, sugar and rice sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Aytan

texts.en: Aytan (her brother is pictured) is 24 years old. She is currently settled in the Absheron region. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Gubadli region in Azerbaijan. She has been in the general store business for two years. She would like a loan of $1200 to buy more goods for her store.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Nguyen Thi T. joined TYM Fund since 2002. Before joining TYM Fund, her life was very difficult. Her husband passed away early, leaving her with 3 young children who all need to go to school. With the money borrowed from TYM Fund, Ms. T. invested in breeding animals and growing plants. Her main family income comes from her large garden. Every year she earns about 30,000,000 VND (equivalent to 1875 USD) from the fruit trees. Currently, besides investing in the fruit trees, her family also invests in planting trained trees. This new business has been developing quite well so Ms. T. and her family is better off now. Her children are also grown up and able to help her with some housework and planting and nurturing trees. This time Ms. T. would like to borrow 12,000,000 VND (equivalent to 725 USD) to continue to invest in planting trained trees and buying more pots. Her average income is 5,000,000 VND per month (equivalent to 312 USD)

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị T. Tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2002. Trước khi trưa tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn, chồng mất sớm một mình chị nuôi 3 con nhỏ đang trong độ tuôi ăn học. Khi tham gia Quỹ được vay vốn chị đã đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt, với thuận lợi gia đình chị có vườn rộng nên nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị chủ yếu là cây ăn quả. Hàng năm gia đình chị thu nhâp từ cây ăn quả 30.000.000đ. Hiên nay ngoài đầu tư vốn vào vườn cây ăn quả gia đình chị còn chồng cây cảnh. Việc đầu tư vốn có hiệu quả nên kinh tế gia đình chị đã phát triển rõ rệt. Các con chị hiện đã lớn và giúp đỡ chị được các công việc trong gia đình như làm vuờn và chăm sóc cây cảnh. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 12.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua giống cây cảnh và chậu cảnh. Thu nhập bình quân: 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Growing

loans.name: Winfrida

texts.en:
Winfrida J. is married with a two-year-old child. She has been selling vegetables since 2007. Every day she works from 9am to 9pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Winfrida now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables -- particularly tomatoes -- for her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Dinh  Thi

texts.vi:
In 2002, Mrs. Dinh Thi H. joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam). For the first loan, Mrs. H. borrowed 2,000,000 VND (equivalent to 125 USD) and used it to raise pigs. She soon realized that this investment brings good profit, so she continues to use her next loans to expand her business model. Her business is doing very good. Each year she sells about 2 tons of pork. Mrs. H. uses her income to save and buy some valuable furniture for the house, such as a motorbike, a refrigerator, etc. She is planning to invest in planting fruit trees. Since she already has a large garden, this project is feasible, and it promises to bring good profit. Mrs. H. has 3 children who have a job and a stable income, and one young kid who is still going to school. This time Mrs. H. would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND (equivalent to 550 USD) to continue to invest in raising animals and farming. Her family's average income is 3,000,000 VND per month (equivalent to 185 USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Năm 2002 chị Đinh Thị H. tham gia vào Quỹ. Vòng vốn đầu tiên gia đình chị xin vay 2.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Sau 1 vòng vốn thấy rằng việc đầu tư vào chăn nuôi sẽ đem lại hiệu quả cao, các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị đã mạnh dạn vay mức vốn cao hơn và mô hình chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đã mở rộng. Chăn nuôi thuân lợi hàng năm gia đình chị xuất ra thị trường khoảng 2 tấn lợn thịt. Thu nhập từ chăn nuôi gia đình chị đã tích lũy và mua sắm đựợc nhiều trang thiết bị có giá trị phục vụ cho sinh hoạt như xe máy, tủ lạnh ..... Tới đây ra đình chị đang có kế hoạch đầu tư vốn vào trồng cây ăn quả, với thuận lợi gia đình chị có diện tích vườn rất rộng nên đây cũng một dự án có tính khả thi và cho thu nhập cao. Hiện tại gia đình chị có 3 con đang đi làm và đều có thu nhập hàng tháng ổn định, 1 con còn nhỏ đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Thu nhập bình quân. 3.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising and growing

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi H. is 40 years old. She joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2002. With more than 15 years of experience in tailoring, she uses all of her loans in her tailor sH.. With her experience and cleverness, her sH. always attracts a lot of customers. Her income is very stable. Mrs. H.'s husband is pretty active. He is a businessman, and during his mean time, he also helps her with the sH.. Now Mrs. H. has a good tailor sH., in which there is a variety of clothes available. Her two children are going to school. She wants to borrow 15,000,000 VND (equivalent to 925 USD) to invest in her tailor sH.. Her average income is 5,000,000 VND per month (equivalent to 310 USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Hợp 40 tuổi, Tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2002 với hơn 15 năm làm nghề may mặc nên các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ gia đình chị đều đầu tư vốn vào cửa hiệu may. Có nhiều năm kinh nghiệm trọng nghề lại là người khéo tay nên số lượng khách hàng đến cửa hiệu may của gia đình chị rất động. Từ đó nên kinh tế gia đình chị rất ổn định, chồng chị là người chịu khó năng động nghề nghiệp chính của anh là buôn bán, những lúc nhàn dỗi anh vẫn thường phụ giúp chị trong công việc may. Hiện nay gia đình chị có một cửa hiệu may khá khang trang với các mặt hàng vải may quẩn áo cũng rất phong phú. 2 con chị hiện đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư vào hiệu may. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: tailoring

loans.name: Constancia's Wema Group

texts.en:
Constancia is 32 years old. She is married with one eight-year-old child. She has been selling clothes since 1999. Every day, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Constancia will use her loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her group members Farida and Zaina, who have businesses in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Dau Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dau Thi H., 48 years old, joined TYM in 2001. Before joining, her family had met a lot of difficulties paying for food and her children education as their only source of income was farming. When TYM came to her village, her family decided to participate. With the first loan of 2 million VND, she bought breeding pigs. Realize how profitable this business can be with the right method and right amount of effort, she keep borrowing more in the coming loan cycle and has achieved immense success. Currently, she is also breeding chickens and ducks alongside her pigs. 3 of her children have found a stable job, earning 3.5 million VND per month while the other 2 are still in school. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 12 million VND to keep investing in her breeding business. Her monthly income is 5 million VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Đậu Thị Hoàng 48 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2001. Trước khi trưa tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn, vất vả, số con đông nguồn thu nhập của gia đình chủ yếu là làm ruộng. Khi Quỹ triển khai trên địa bàn, chị đã bàn bạc cùng với chồng tham gia để vay vốn phát triển kinh tế. Vòng vốn đầu gia đình chị xin vay 2.000.000đ mua lợn giống sau một vòng vốn vay cũng là lúc gia đình chị xuất được 2 lứa lợn. Nhận thấy việc đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi là phù hợp với điều kiện gia đình, nên các vòng vốn tiếp theo gia đình chị đều vay vốn ở mức cao đầu tư vào chăn nuôi với mô hình lớn hơn. Hiện nay ngoài việc chăn nuôi lợn gia đình chị còn đầu tư vào chăn gà thịt. Thực tế gia đình chị đang nuôi 7 con lợn thịt và 200 con gà thịt. 3 con chị hiện đã lớn và đã đi làm cho thu nhập đều đặn 3.500.000đ/ tháng, 2 con hiện đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 12.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Even though she is relatively young, Ms. Nguyen Thi H. has a very good business skill. Since joining TYM in 2004 all of her loan has been of large amount of money and she has always paid them on time. Her project was to create a entertainment area with billiard and table-tennis. She was only able to buy 2 billiard tables in the first cycle but with each cycle and more success she has been able to purchase one more table-tennis table. Her family daily income is 200.000 NVD. Apart from this, she also provide refreshments there. In this cycle, she would like to borrow 10 million VND to continue to invest into this business. Her monthly income is about 6 million VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Mặc dù tuổi đời còn rất trẻ nhưng chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng lại có khả năng kinh doanh rất tốt, tham gia Quỹ năm 2004 các vòng vốn chị đều vay ở mức cao. Dự án kinh doanh của gia đình chị là đầu tư dịch vụ thể thao giải trí Bi a và bóng bàn. Ban đầu khi tham gia vào Quỹ mức vốn được vay còn thấp nên chị chỉ mua 2 bàn bi a sau quá trình kinh doanh của gia đình chị diễn ra thuận lợi cho thu nhâp cao, gia đình chị đã bàn bạc và mua thêm 2 bàn bi a và 1 bàn chơi bóng bàn. Hiện nay thu nhập từ việc kinh doanh dịch vụ mỗi ngày bình quân 200.000đ. Ngoài thu nhập từ dịch vụ bóng bàn và bi a gia đình chị còn phục vụ khách hàng khi có nhu cầu giải khát tại gia đình. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư kinh doanh và sửa lại cửa hàng. Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Gisela

texts.en:
Gisela is 29 years old. She is married with three children, aged eight, six and four. She has owned and run a small shop since 2004. Every day, she works from 6am to 12:30pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $450 from her sales.

Gisela will use her loan to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Leah's Alfa Na Omega Group

texts.en:
Leah is 40 years old. She is married with one 16-year-old child. She has been selling clothes since 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Leah will use her loan to buy more clothing inventory for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who have businesses selling bites, shoes, cosmetics and operating a salon.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Phạm Thị Thành, 48 yeaqrs old, is a TYM member since 2002. Her house's location is ideal for a business. She and her family run a refreshment shop right in their house serving the locals. They also supply drinks to other businesses as well. They started small, with time they have expanded their operation. They have invested a lot of money into their busibess, hundred millions VND. Their income is very stable, 300.000 VND a day. Their business plan is to offer more beer brands and soft drink variety. Their children are still attending school. This time, she is requesting a loan of 16.000.000 VND. Her family income is 7.000.000 VND a month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Tham gia Quỹ năm 2002, chị Phạm Thị Thành 48 tuổi với thuận lợi gia đình chị gần mặt đường nên rất phù hợp cho công việc kinh doanh. Hiện nay gia đình chị kinh doanh các mặt hàng giải khát như bia và nước ngọt phuc vụ khách có nhu cầu giải khát tại cửa hàng gia đình chị, ngoài ra cửa hàng gia đình chị còn là nơi cung cấp cho các cho các gia đình khác cũng kinh doanh giải khát quanh khu vực. Tù những đồng vốn vay nhỏ lẻ đến nay gia đình chị đã ngày càng phát triển kinh tế số vốn đầu tư vào kinh doanh là rất lớn, hàng 100 triệu đồng. Nguồn thu nhập từ kinh doanh rất đều đặn bình quân 300.000đ/ ngày. Kế hoạch của gia đình chị trong thời gian tới sẽ mở thêm nhiều mặt hàng Bia và các loại nước ngọt khác để có thể mở rộng thị trường kinh doanh, các con chị hiện đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 16.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào kinh doanh. Thu nhập bình quân. 7.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: refreshment shop

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Đào Thị D. is 30 years old. She participated in TYM since 2004. She invests all her loans into her bridal beauty salon. Before joining TYM she did not have capital to invest into her beauty salon so she was having a lot of difficulties because she did not have all the make up products to satisfy her clients's needs. After joining TYM, she has bough all the necessary make up products. Her clientele slowly builds up. She also takes make up classes to perfect her skills. Her salon attracts a lot of new customers since she has all the make up products abd the skills. On top of doing bridal make up, she also rents áo dài for special occasion. Her family income is stable. This round she is requesting a loan of 9.000.000 VND. Her monthly income is around 5.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Đào Thị D. 30 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2004 vay vốn gia đình chị đều đầu tư vào cửa hiệu trang điểm cô dâu. Những năm trưa tham gia vào Quỹ do còn thiếu vốn nên công việc kinh doanh hiệu trang điểm cô dâu của gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn, một số các đồ phục vụ cho việc trang điểm chưa đáp ứng được nhu cầu thực tế của xã hội, khi tham gia Quỹ chị đã vay vốn đầu tư mua sắm những đồ cần thiết phục vụ cho trang điểm cô dâu, từ đó cửa hiệu của chị dần dần đáp ứng được nhu cầu số đông khách hàng bản thân chị cũng thường xuyên đi học thêm các lớp đào tạo về trang điểm. Quy mô cửa hàng được nâng cấp tay nghề được nâng cao nên cửa hiệu của chị ngày càng đông khách. Ngoài phục vụ vào các mùa cưới hỏi gia đình chị còn cho thuê áo dài phục vụ các lễ hội. Hiện tai kinh tế gia đình chị tương đối ổn định. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào cửa hiệu trang điểm. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha S. is married with four children aged 25, 23, 19 and 16. She became a food seller in 1996. Every day, she works from 7am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more food items like rice, maize, flour and bananas to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
A TYM member since 2002, Ms Nguyễn Thị L. owns a general store. She is 40 years old. She runs the store right in her house which has a good location and a street front so it is very suitable for her business. Her customers are the locals from the neighborhood. Her store offers lots of products because she invests a lot in her store. It has a good customer base. The income from the store is 150.000 VND a day. In the beginning of 2008, noticing that the customer demand had increased, she started to offer bottled water. This proved to be a good move as bottled water is safer for consumption than tap water. Customers had flocked to her store to buy bottled water. She has 3 children, 1 is already working to help the family and the other 2 are still going to school. Her husband is working with her. This round she is requesting a loan of 18.000.000 VND to continue investing in her store. Her family income is 5.000.000 VND a month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2002, chị Nguyễn Thị L. 40 tuổi nghề nghiệp kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa. Hiện tại gia đình chị mở một cửa hàng tại nhà rất thuận tiện cho gia đình chị trong việc kinh doanh vì nhà chị sống ngay mặt đường, khách hàng của gia đình chị là các bà con đang sống tại đia phương trong xã, có vốn đầu tư vào cửa hàng nên các mặt hàng của gia đình chị cũng rất phong phú và đáp ứng được nhu cầu tại địa phương. Thu nhập đều đặn bình quân 150.000đ/ ngày. Thấy nhu cầu của người dân nâng cao đầu năm 2008 chị đã đầu tư thêm vốn mở thêm mặt hàng nước lọc, đây cũng là một mặt hàng với giá thành phù hợp và đảm bảo an toàn về vê sinh nên bà con tại địa phương tìm đến cửa hàng chị ngày càng đông. Chị có 3 con, 1 con đã đi làm phụ giúp kinh tế gia đình, 2 con đang trong độ tuôi ăn học, chồng chị cùng chị kinh doanh. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 18.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào hàng tạp hóa. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Invest in her general store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. is 24 years old and married with a six-year-old child. She began selling fish and cassava in 2008. Every day, she works from 5am to 8pm and earns a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Elizabeth now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and cassava for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish and cassava for her business.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Her husband passed away so Ms Nguyễn Thi M. had to raise her 2 young children by herself. It was difficult. She started participating in TYM fund in 2002. She opend a tailor shop right in her home. She is a skillful businesswoman and has a lot of experience as a tailor. She has all kind of customers but her main clientele are young men and women since appearance is important for them. After a few years, Ms M. has opened a furniture store with all her savings and loans from TYM. Despite the fact that this is a new store, people do know about it and come to the store. This time Ms M. is seeking 9.000.000 VND to invest in her furniture store, buying wood. Her monthly income is on average 6.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Chồng mất sớm nên chị Nguyễn Thi M. vất vả nuôi 2 con còn nhỏ hiện đang trong độ tuổi ăn học. Tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2002 vòng vốn ban đầu chị vay Quỹ chị đã đầu tư vào cửa hàng may mặc tại gia đình, với bản chất là người phụ nữ khéo léo lại có nhiều năm kinh nghiệm trong nghề nên khách hàng của gia đình chị rất đông, khách hàng của chị cũng rất đa dạng đầy đủ các tầng lớp nhưng chủ yếu số đông vẫn là thanh niên nam nữ đây cũng là đối tượng có nhu cầu lớn trong việc sắm sửa may mặc. Sau nhiều năm làm nghề chị đã tích lũy được số vốn kết hợp với việc vay vốn của Quỹ, chị đã kinh doanh thêm một gian hàng chuyên bán đồ gỗ mặc dù mới kinh doanh nhưng cửa hàng của gia đình chị cũng được nhiều người biết đến. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư thêm vốn vào cửa hàng kinh doanh đồ gỗ. Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Kifayat

texts.en: Kifayat is the mother of 2 children.She was born in 1972. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Djabrayil region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, settled in Baku city. She has been working as a cook in this cafe for 7 years.  Now she needs a loan of US$ 1200 to buy the necessary things for improving services to customers so she will get more income from her work.

loans.use: to buy the necessary things for improving services to customers

loans.name: Eva's Titanic Group

texts.en:
Eva S. is 29 years old and single. She has been selling hardware since 2002. Every day she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Eva wants a loan to buy more hardware items for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who have businesses keeping hens, operating a salon and selling clothes.

loans.use: To buy more hardware items to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is twenty-eight-year-old Khadija I. from Dar es Salaam. She owns a beauty salon in the city centre that she established in 2007 and now runs with one employee.

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

Khadija has been making monthly profits of approximately US$ 110 from her salon and is now requesting a loan of US$ 275. She intends to use this money to buy a hair dryer and other hair products for her salon. In the future, she aspires to increase the quantity and range of her business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a hair dryer and other beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Đào joined TYM fund in 2007. She lives in the district of Kim Động, Hưng Yên province with her husband and their 3 children. Her main occupation is raising pigs. Her husband and their oldest son are woodworkers. Currently, her family has a batch of 30 pigs. Since she has a lot of experience in this domain, this helps yielding good profit and permits her to have a stable income. They have saved 3.000.000 VND from her pig business and her husband's salary to provide good education to their other 2 children. Their living condition is good. This time Ms Đào is seeking a loan of 9.000.000 VND to invest more in her pig raising business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Đào tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007.Chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại huyện Kim Động tỉnh Hưng Yên.Hàng ngày chị chủ yếu chăn nuôi lợn còn chồng chị và người con lớn làm nghề mộc. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi khoảng 30 con lợn thịt. Với những kinh nghiệm đã được tích luỹ trong nhiều năm nên công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị có nhiều thuận lợi và cho thu nhập ổn định. Với thu nhập 3.000.000đ từ chăn nuôi và làm mộc gia đình chị đã có điều kiện để đầu tư cho 2 con ăn học và cải thiện cuộc sống gia đình. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: Raise pigs

loans.name: Fatuma's Buffalo Group

texts.en:
Fatuma J. is 25 years old and single. She began selling clothes in 2008. Every day she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

Fatuma is applying for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who also have clothing sales businesses.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Scholar's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Scholar J. is 31 years old. She is married with two children aged twelve and ten. She has been a clothes seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Scholar now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes to sell. She will share this loan with her group members Subira and Shamim, who have businesses dealing in juice and oil sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca N. is 25 years old. She is married with three children aged eleven, nine and one. She has been selling vegetables since 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Rebeca is applying for a loan to increase her vegetable inventory.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
