Mambo from Tanzania! This is fifty-year-old Zuhura S. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children and is also responsible for supporting two other young relatives because they are orphans. Zuhura owns a Mama Lishe or local café in Dar where she serves up delicious local food.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be.

The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

Josephine, along with one employee, also works as a caterer for local businesses, which has enabled her to increase her monthly profits to US$ 170. She has borrowed and successfully repaid two prior loans from SELFINA for US$ 275 each. This time, she is requesting a larger loan of US$ 525 to purchase additional cooking equipment to help fulfill her catering orders and buy extra cooking supplies on a larger scale. In the future, Zuhura hopes to do well enough to expand her business to another location.

loans.use: To purchase additional catering and cooking supplies

loans.name: Hajra's Alfa Na Omega Group

texts.en:
Hajra K. is 25 years old. She is married with one three-year-old child. She has been selling clothes since in 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250.

Hajra is applying for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her group member Fatuma, who has a business selling fish and cassava.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Husna's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Husna A. is 40 years old and married with three children aged twenty, seventeen and twelve. She has been tailoring since 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $250.

Husna is applying for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, who have businesses owning a shop, selling vegetables and in bites sales.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-eight-year-old Amina from Dar es Salaam; she is married and has four children. Amina runs a small stall from which she sells tomatoes in downtown Dar es Salaam. The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge.

A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Amina started her stall in 2000 and has been earning monthly profits of US$ 150 from it since. This is Amina’s second loan from SELFINA; she successfully repaid her first loan of US$ 275. She is now requesting US$ 625 in order to buy large quantities of tomatoes in bulk and to renovate her stall. Thank you for supporting Amina in her efforts to improve the volume and sales of her business!

loans.use: To renovate her stall and to buy produce in bulk

loans.name: Elsavar

texts.en: Elsavar was born in 1971. He is  an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He settled in the Fuzuli region, Mahmudliu village. This young man is married and has 2 children. 5 years ago, he started an auto repair business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy necessary tools for auto repairing.

loans.use: to buy necessary tools for auto repair

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Ashura is a forty-year-old married woman with four children from Dar es Salaam. Additionally she is responsible for supporting a fifteen-year-old relative who is an orphan.

Ashura owns and operates a small stall from which she sells roasted fish. She buys fresh fish daily from local fishermen as they come in with their morning catch, and then roasts and sells these fish either in the fish market or along the roads of Dar. Given its location along the Indian Ocean, fish is plentiful in the waters around Dar and is a staple of the local Tanzanian diet.

Ashura is an enterprising micro-entrepreneur who is taking advantage of a local need to make monthly profits of US$ 240. She has borrowed and successfully repaid a prior loan from SELFINA for US$ 150. This time, she is requesting US$ 275 in order to buy additional supplies of cooking oil as well as to buy more fish daily to meet the growing demands of her customers!

The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of fish and other cooking supplies

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-nine-year-old Mwanahamisi M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children between the ages of twenty-two and ten. Additionally, she cares for a relative who is an orphan. Mwanahamisi operates a Mama Lishe or local café in the city where she serves up delicious food.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

Mwanahamisi, along with one employee, works long hours to earn monthly profits of US$ 140 from her business. This is her third loan with SELFINA. In the past, she has borrowed and successfully repaid two loans of US$ 275 each. This time, she is requesting a larger loan of US$ 525 to purchase additional cooking equipment and extra cooking supplies on a larger scale. In the future, Mwanahamisi hopes to do well enough to expand her business to another location.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Farida

texts.en: Farida (her son is pictured) was born in 1963. She lives in Khachmaz region. This woman is the mother of 3 children. 6 years ago she started a cattle breeding business. Now she needs a loan of US$ 875 to buy a calf and the baling presses to improve her cattle breeding.

loans.use: to buy a calf and baling presses

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex E. sells jeans, shirts, and other items of clothing. He is single and focused on developing his future but his income is not sufficient for Alex achieve his dreams. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business

loans.name: Josephiner

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-one-year-old Josephiner S. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children. Additionally, she cares for two relatives who board with her. Josephiner operates a Mama Lishe or local café in the city where she serves up delicious traditional Tanzanian cuisine.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

Josephiner, along with three employees, works long hours to earn monthly profits of US$ 170 from her business. This is her third loan with SELFINA. In the past, she has borrowed and successfully repaid loans of US$ 225 and US$ 425 each. This time, she is requesting a larger loan of US$ 625 to purchase additional cooking equipment and cooking supplies on a larger scale. In the future, Josephiner hopes to do well enough to open another business.

Josephiner is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why the large majority of clients repay their loans. A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or Kiva.org) for the first time, ask anxiously, “But how do you make sure people pay back? Won’t they just take the money?” The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually 'the poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people.

Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant, for a number of reasons. Firstly, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk. More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive. The incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another…The incentive is having on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies in bulk for her cafe

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi A. sells foodstuffs like yams, plantains, and tomatoes. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Esi and her 3 children. Demand for her foodstuffs is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Parvana

texts.en: Parvana is the mother of 2 children. She was born in 1981. This young woman lives in Khachmaz region. 6 years ago she started cattle breeding. Now she needs a loan of US$ 875 to buy 2 calves.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. sells fabric and clothing. She is a single parent and her income is not sufficient for Aba and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.
She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

texts.en:
Agnes D. sells foodstuffs such as plantains and tomatoes at the market. She is a single parent and her income is not sufficient for Agnes and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

texts.en:
Aba O. M. operates a chop bar. Her income as a single parent is not sufficient for Aba and her 2 children. Demand for her food is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.
She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi E. is a baker who bakes bread and other baked goods. Her income is not sufficient for Esi to live off of. Demand for her baked goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Adwowa

texts.en:
Adwowa E. sells yams, tomatoes, and beans at the market. Her income as a single parent is not sufficient for Adwowa and her 6 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Sakhiba

texts.en: Sakhiba (her husband is pictured) lives in the Khachmaz region. She is 45 and has three children. Her and her husband have been running a farming business for ten years. They would like a loan of $1200 to buy more seeds for fruits and vegetables to help improve and increase their farming business.

loans.use: to buy seeds (fruits and vegetables)

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama K. sells tomatoes, peppers, onions and other foodstuffs. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Ama and her 6 children. Demand for the foods she sells is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en: A. is a pharmacist and also sells drugs. He is married, but his wife's income is not sufficient for John A. and their 5 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John A. A. sells groceries and frozen meat. He is married, but his wife's income is not sufficient for John and his 4 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba W. sells wood and most of her customers are carpenters. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Aba and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Ophelia

texts.en:
Ophelia E. sells sugar cane and sugar cane syrup. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Ophelia and her 4 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex K. M. is a distiller who produces sugar cane syrup for sale. He is married, but his wife's income is not sufficient for Alex K. and his 5 children. Demand for his syrup is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa P. sells saucepans, fabric, and other items. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Theresa and her husband to live on. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị D. tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1998. Ban đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Sau đó nhận thấy nhu cầu sử dụng cây cảnh tại địa phương ngày càng tăng nên gia đình chị quyết định đầu tư vào trồng cây cảnh để bán. Chồng chị là cán bộ hưu trí  nên anh cũng dành nhiều thời gian để chăm sóc cây cảnh tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Ngoài thu nhập từ chăn nuôi, bán cây cảnh gia đình chị còn tận dụng đất vườn để trồng thêm cây ăn quả vì thế thu nhập của gia đình rất ổn định. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 18.000.000đ để đầu tư vào trồng cây cảnh và chăn nuôi.
Thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị D. has participated in the TYM Fund since 1998. In the beginning, she borrow money to invest into rearing livestock. Thereafter, she recognized the there was a demand for ornamental landscaping plants in her region therefore the family decided to invest in a landscaping plants retail business. Her husband is a retired government employee therefore he has time to tend to the plants to increase the family's income. In addition to the income from rearing livestock and selling ornamental plants, the family also uses some of the available land to grow fruit-bearing plants - due to all of this the family's income is rather steady. For this round of loans, she wishes to raise 18,000,000 VND to invest further into their ornamental plants and livestock rearing business. Their income is 3,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock and growing ornamental plants to sell

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Gái tham gia Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2006. Là gia đình thuần nông nên thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu là từ chăn nuôi và trồng trọt. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương do thiếu vốn nên gia đình chị chỉ tập trung vào chăn nuôi lợn. Sau khi nhận được vốn vay của Quỹ chị đã mạnh dạn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi bò. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi 1 con bò thịt và một con bò sinh sản. Dự án chăn nuôi bò đã giúp cho thu nhập của gia đình chị được cải thiện đáng kể. Ngoài thời gian phụ giup vợ trong việc chăn nuôi chồng chị Gái còn làm thêm nghề xe ôm để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị Gái luôn mong muốn có thu nhập ổn định hơn để đầu tư cho 2 con ăn học và cải thiện cuộc sống gia đình. Chị mong muốn vòng vốn tới được vay 9.000.000đ để mua thức ăn phục vụ cho việc chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gái has participated in the TYM Fund since 2006. She has a simple family which is why the family's income mainly comes from rearing livestock and farming. Before joining the Fund, the family focused their efforts on raising pigs for the lack of capital. After having received a loan, she assertively invested in cattle rearing. Today, the family is raising one cow to sell for its meat and another cow for breeding. The project of raising cattle has helped to gradually improve the family income. Outside of the time he puts in to help his wife tend to the livestock, Mrs. Gái's husband also works as a hired motorbike driver to increase the family income. Mrs. Gái has always dreamt of having a more steady income to put money towards her two children's education and give her family a better life. She wishes to borrow 9,000,000 VND to purchase materials and supplies for her livestock rearing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies and materials for livestock rearing

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita A. sells fabric, shoes, and bags, and she also makes doughnuts for sale. She is married, but her husband's income alone is not sufficient for the two of them, although they have no children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Thi Hai

texts.vi:
MRs. P. Thi Hai, 48 years old, has 3 children, 1 of whom is still schooling. In 2001, she joined the TYM Fund to obtain loans and invest in raising livestock. Besides livestock, she also plants fruit trees to take advantage of her large garden. After 7 years of membership, thanks to the loans and her hard work, her family's income has increased and the quality of life has improved. This time, she would like to borrow 12,000,000VND (725USD) to continue investing in rearing pigs and planting fruit trees.

Translated from Vietnamese by P. Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị Hải năm nay 48 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 3 người con trong đó có 1 con đang tuổi đi học. Năm 2001 chị tham gia vàoQuỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Ngoài chăn nuôi, tận dụng vườn rộng gia đình chị còn trồng thêm các loại cây ăn quả để tăng thêm thu nhập.Qua 7 năm, nhờ có nguồn vốn vay của Quỹ và sự cố gắng nỗ lực làm ăn kinh tế gia đình chị đã phát triển, cuộc sống gia đình chị đã được cải thiện hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 12.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và trồng cây ăn quả.

loans.use: Rearing pigs and planting fruit trees

loans.name: Thi Ngo

texts.vi:
Mrs. Ngo, 42 years old, has 2 schooling children. Joined the TYM Fund in 2002, she used the first loan to invest in rearing pigs. Currently, besides raising livestock and farming, she has a small store selling drinks. With the stable income from farming, livestock and business, she is able to send her children to school and purchase more home products. This time, she would like to borrow 14,000,000VND (850USD) to expand her business and further improve her family's economy. Her monthly income is 3,000,000VND (about 200USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Ngọ năm nay 42 tuổi. Gia đình chị hiện có 2 con đang tuổi đi học. Tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2002, vòng vốn đầu chị đã sử dụng để chăn nuôi lợn. Đến nay ngoài chăn nuôi và trồng trọt chị còn có một cửa hàng nhỏ kinh doanh đồ uống giải khát. Với thu nhập ổn định từ chăn nuôi, trồng trọt và kinh doanh chị đã đầu tư cho các con ăn học đầy đủ và mua sắm thêm các trang thiết bị trong gia đình. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 14.000.000đ để đầu tư mở rộng kinh doanh, chăn nuôi phát triển kinh tế gia đình . Thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Raising livestock and investing in drink store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth T. is a fishmonger who buys fresh fish and then processes them for sale. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 2 children. Demand for her fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Thi Khan

texts.vi:
Mrs. Khan, 36 years old, lives with her husband and her 2 school-going daughters. In 2003, she joined the TYM Fund and obtained loans to invest in her tailor shop. As a skillful seamstress, she has been purchasing more types of materials using the loans so as to satisfy the demand of the customers. Therefore, more and more customers has been visiting her shop. Her family's income is also increasing. Besides working as a electrician, Mrs. Khan's husband helps her taking care of the daughters so that she has more time to do the tailoring. This time, she would like to borrow 15,000,000VND (925USD) to invest in her tailor shop. her monthly income is 3,000,000VND (about 200USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Khẩn năm nay 36 tuổi, chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con gái đang tuổi đi học. Năm 2003 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương và xin vay vốn để đầu tư vào cửa hàng may. Vốn là người thợ may khéo tay, có thêm vốn chị đầu tư mua thêm nhiều loại vải khác phục vụ nhu cầu đa dạng của khách hàng nên của hàng của chị ngày càng đông khách. Thu nhập của gia đình chị nhờ đó cũng tăng lên. Chồng chị Khẩn ngoài thời gian sửa chữa điện còn giúp chị chăm sóc 2 con nên chị cũng có nhiều thời gian để đầu tư cho công việc may mặc. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng may. Thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Tailoring

loans.name: Thi Lap

texts.vi:
Mrs. Lap joined the TYM Fund in 1998. Before that her family's income only came from farming and rearing pigs. After joining the Fund and having more capital, she decided to invest in raising cows to breed and sell. Currently, she has 2 cows to breed and 3 cows to sell. Apart from livestock and farming, her family can also rely on fishing so her family's income is very stable. After 10 years of membership, Mrs. Lap has been one of the members who use their loans effectively. This time, she would like to borrow 18,000,000VND (1,100USD) to continue investing in raising cows. Her monthly income is 4,000,000VND (about 266USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lập tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1998. Trước đây gia đình chị chỉ trồng trọt chăn nuôi lợn để phát triển kinh tế gia đình . Sau khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương có thêm nguồn vốn vay gia đình chị đã đầu tư để chăn nuôi thêm bò thịt và bò sinh sản. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi 2 con bò sinh sản và 3 con bò thịt. Ngoài chăn nuôi, trồng trọt gia đình chị còn có thêm nghề đánh bắt cá vì thế thu nhập của gia đình chị rất ổn định. Qua 10 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương đến nay chị Lập là một trong những thành viên sử dụng vốn rất hiệu quả. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 18.000.000 đ để ttiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi bò Thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Raising cows

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. sells fish alongside ladies' wear. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Mary and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Thi Long

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Long joined the TYM Fund in 1999. After 9 years of borrowing to invest in farming and raising livestock effectively, her family's economy is now very stable with the monthly income of 3,000,000VND (about 200USD). Currently, her family focuses mainly on planting maize to produce animal feeds for pigs and cows. Her children are all grown-up and have stable jobs. This time, she would like to borrow 15,000,000VND (925USD) to invest in rearing pigs and cows to further improve her family's economy.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Long tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999. Trong 9 năm tham gia Quỹ vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và trồng trọt hiệu quả đến nay kinh tế gia đình chị rất ổn đinh với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Hiện nay gia đình chị chủ yếu tập trung vào trồng 2 mẫu ngô làm thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi lợn, bò. Các con của chị đều đã trưởng thành và đều có công việc ổn định. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, bò để phát triển kinh tế gia đình.

loans.use: Raising and growing

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. T. is 41 years old. Her husband is a ship pilot; therefore, he has to be away from home for a long time. She has to raise the animals to earn money and spend time raising her 2 children. In 2001, she joined the TYM Fund to borrow money. Because of her experience and her hard work, she used the borrowed money effectively. Her living conditions are improved. She earns 225 USD/month. She uses her money in sending her children to school, furnishing her home, and expanding her farm. This time, she wants to borrow 925 USD to invest more in raising animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

 Chị T. năm nay 41 tuổi. Chồng chị làm nghề lái tàu nên thường xuyên phải đi làm xa nhà vì thế ngoài công việc chăn nuôi, trồng trọt chị còn phải dành thời gian để dạy dỗ 2 con đang tuổi đến trường. Năm 2001 chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Với kinh nghiệm chăn nuôi và sự chănm chỉ lao động chị đã sử dụng vốn rất hiệu quả vì thế thu nhập của gia đình chị đã ngày càng được cải thiện. Với thu nhập ổn định 3500.000đ/ tháng chị T. không chỉ đầu tư cho các con ăn học mà còn có điều kiện để sửa sang nhà cửa và mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi phát triển kinh tế gia đình.

loans.use: Rasing animals

loans.name: Yasinta

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-eight-year-old Yasinta from Dar es Salaam. She is divorced with four children under the age of eighteen. She also takes care of a fourteen-year-old relative who is an orphan because his parents passed away from HIV AIDS.

Yasinta owns a small "duka" or neighborhood shop in the city where she sells common household and grocery items. She established the store in 1996 and currently runs it with the help of her children to earn monthly profits of US$ 71. She is requesting a loan of US$ 875 in order to obtain capital to expand the range and quantity of products available at her store.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies in bulk for her store

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph K. M. is married and has four children. He has received a middle school education. Joseph sells drinks including soft drinks, juice boxes, and Malta. Malta is a non-alcoholic beer that is very popular in Ghana. When Joseph is not manning his shop, he also works as a taxi driver. His shop is in Elmina, and he opened it in 2004. His wife works in the shop when Joseph is driving his taxi. Joseph uses his income to pay for school fees, rent, electricity and water bills.

Joseph will use the loan to purchase soft drinks including Coke, Fanta, and Malta. With the new profits from his expanded business, Joseph plans to construct a better building for his shop and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks including coke, fanta, and Malta

loans.name: Dang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dang Thi T., 31 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2003. With a starting fund of 80 USD, she invested in raising animals. However, it was not very profitable. Therefore, she decided to invest in selling beverages. Her husband, beside being a taxi driver, also helps her in her business. With an average income of 200 USD/month, she is now able to send her children to school and improve living conditions. This time, she wants to borrow 1100 USD to buy more beverages to sell.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

 Chị Đặng Thị Tuyền năm nay 31 tuổi, chị tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Với số vốn vay ban đầu là 1.000.000đ chị đã đầu tư vào chăn nuôi nhưng hiệu quả đem lại không cao vì thế vòng vốn sau chị đã quyết định đầu tư vốn để kinh doanh nước giải khát. Chồng chị ngoài thời gian đi làm nghề lái xe cũng phụ giúp chị trong kinh doanh nên công việc của chị rất thuận lợi. Với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng gia đình chị đã có điều kiện để đầu tư cho các con ăn học và cải thiện cuộc sống,. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay18.000.000đ để đau tư mua thêm hàng về bán.

loans.use: Business in beverages

loans.name: Matha

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is Matha W. from Dar es Salaam. She has two adult children and also cares for two teenage children who board with her because they have come from a different part of the country to study in Dar’s schools.

Matha owns a taxi business. She owns a car in which her sole employee drives customers to their desired destinations. Matha currently earns US$ 75 from her business and is requesting a loan of US$ 275 that she intends to put towards the repair and maintenance of her car. She hopes that this will allow her to rent out her car for more hours each day and therefore earn increased profits.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To perform much needed maintenance on her taxi

loans.name: Phamthi

texts.vi:
Before joining the TYM Fund, Mrs. U. faced a lot of difficulties in doing business because her husband passed away and her 2 children were still going to school. In 2003, she joined the TYM Fund to borrow money. At first, she invested in raising chickens. However, later on, she realized that growing decorative plants brought more profits. Therefore, she decided to invest in growing plants. Because she has learned lots of experience from other people, she has a lot of customers. Currently, her 2 children are all grown-up. She and her children work on growing the plants to meet local people’s needs. With an earning of 200 USD/month, their living conditions have improved. This time, she wants to borrow 1100 USD to invest in both raising animals and growing decorative plants.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

 Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương gia đình chị Uẩn gặph rất nhiều khó khăn về kinh tế do chồng chị mất sỡn, các con đang tuổi đến trường.Năm 2003 chị bắt đầu tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương để vay vốn phát triển kinh tế gia đình. . Ban đầu chị vay vốn và đầu tư vào chăn gà nhưng sau đó nhận thấy việc trồng cây cảnh đem lại lợi nhuận cao hơn nên gia đình chị đã quyết đinh đầu tư phần lớn vốn vay vào dự án này. Nhờ chăn chỉ học hỏi kinh nghiệm và khéo tay nên cây cảnh nhà chị được nhiều khách hàng ưa thích. Hiện nay các con chị đều đã trưởng thành nên chị và 2 con tập trung để trồng và chăn sóc cây cảnh bán cho người dân địa phương. Với 3.000.000đ thu nhập ổn định từ chăn nuôi và bán cây cảnh cuộc sống của ba mẹ con chị Uẩn đã được cải thiện rõ rệt. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 18.000.000 đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và trồng cây cảnh .

loans.use: Raising animals and growing decorative plants

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is fifty-eight-year-old Zainabu from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four adult children. She also supports a young relative whose parents passed away from HIV AIDS. Zainabu owns a "duka" or a neighborhood store where she sells essential grocery and household items. She runs a successful store that makes monthly profits of US$ 1,000.

Zainabu is currently requesting a loan of US$ 875 to purchase supplies like rice, beans, cooking oil, soda, beer, and sugar in bulk quantities. She will then retail them for a profit to her customers. In the future, she hopes to open another store.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence the poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk for her store

loans.name: Vuong Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Vuong Thi X., 53 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2001. She owns a small general shop at the supermarket. Besides, she also raises pigs and chickens at home. Therefore, her family economy is very stable. She has 2 children, one of whom is grown-up and has a job. Her husband also helps her in getting the merchandises as well as in raising the animals. This time, she wants to borrow 925 USD to invest in raising the animals and her general store. Her current average income is 200 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

 Chị Vương Thị Xuân năm nay 53 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2001. Hiện tại gia đình chị có một cửa hàng kinh doanh tạp hoá tại chợ. Ngoài kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá gia đình chị còn kết hợp chăn nuôi thêm lợn, gà nên thu nhập rất ổn định.Gia đình chị có 2 con, một con đã trưởng thành và có công việc ổn định. Chồng chị hàng ngày ngoài việc đi lấy hàng về cho chị bán còn giúp đỡ chị trong công việc chăn nuôi nên công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị cũng có nhiều thuận lợi. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá Thu nậhp 3.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: general store and raising animals

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-year-old Salima from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children under the age of fifteen. She is also financially responsible for another child who is a relative. Salima owns and runs a stall from which she sells essential grocery items. The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge.

A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Additionally, Salima has capitalized on Dar es Salaam’s proximity to the Indian Ocean and the fondness of its residents for fish to sell roasted fish at her genge. This helps her earn some extra income. She currently makes US$ 90 per month from sales at her genge.

Salima is requesting a loan of US$ 225 to purchase additional fish, cooking oil, and cooking fuel for her stall. She is hopeful that selling more fish will help her earn higher profits.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase supplies in bulk for her grocery store

loans.name: Joane

texts.en:
Joane B. owns a grocery store and sells all kinds of groceries like milo, milk, biscuits, and others. But the picture was taken when she was serving a client who needed an item she had run out of at her shop but had at her house which is very close to her shop. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Joane and her 2 children.

Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for US$ 600 of additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Rahabu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is twenty-five-year-old Rahabu from Dar es Salaam, who is married and has a toddler. She also takes care of a sixteen-year-old relative who is an orphan. Rahabu owns and, with the help of an employee, runs a small store from which she sells essential grocery items. The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge.

A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

This is Rahabu’s second loan with SELFINA; she has already successfully paid off a loan of US$ 275. This time she is requesting a loan of US$ 525 in order to buy her wares in bulk. She hopes to retail these for a profit.

Rahabu is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why the large majority of clients repay their loans. A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or Kiva.org) for the first time, ask anxiously, “But how do you make sure people pay back? Won’t they just take the money?” The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually 'the poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people.

Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant, for a number of reasons. Firstly, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk. More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive. The incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another…The incentive is having on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase supplies in bulk for her stall

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-year-old Grace M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two young children. Additionally she supports a young relative who boards with her while she attends school in Dar.

Grace owns a video store that she runs with the assistance of her husband. In addition to renting out movie videos to customers, they also work as videographers. At occasions like weddings and birthdays, Grace and her husband are available to record your special occasion for posterity!

Grace currently makes monthly profits of US$ 110 from her video store. This is her second loan with SELFINA; she successfully paid back her initial loan of US$ 50 which has allowed her to request a far larger loan this time around. Grace would like US$ 350 to purchase new video cameras and blank tapes. She is hopeful that this will enable her to expand the scale of her business in the near future.

loans.use: To buy video cameras and blank tapes for her video store

loans.name: Medelina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-eight-year-old Medelina M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children (ages nine and fifteen). Medelina is an innovative micro-entrepreneur who owns a groundnut stall in the city. Roasted groundnuts are extremely popular in Dar es Salaam, and Medelina is one of the many vendors who sell them on the roads here!

Since groundnuts are traditionally grown in Dodoma, the capital of Tanzania which is located in the centre of the country, Medelina currently makes US$ 160 from the sale of her nuts and is requesting a loan of US$ 525 for capital to enable her to organize a bulk delivery of groundnuts from Dodoma. She will then roast these at her stall and sell them for a profit to customers unable to resist the tantalizing aroma of these fresh nuts!

Medelina is a veteran customer of SELFINA’s; this is her fourth loan with them. In the past, she has successfully paid off a loan of US$ 275 and two loans of US$ 425. Her successful repayment in the past has allowed her to request a larger sum this time around.

Medelina is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why the large majority of clients repay their loans. A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or Kiva.org) for the first time, ask anxiously, “But how do you make sure people pay back? Won’t they just take the money?” The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually 'the poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient, or educated than ‘ordinary’ people.

Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant, for a number of reasons. Firstly, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk.

More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive. The incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another…The incentive is having on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase groundnuts (peanuts) in bulk for her business

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-five-year-old Flora from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has four children between the ages of seven and twenty-six. Flora owns a beauty salon which she runs with the assistance of two employees. Flora's salon generates approximately US$ 110 in profits each month.

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own.

This is Flora’s second loan with SELFINA. She successfully paid back her initial loan of US$ 225, which has allowed her to request a larger amount this time. Flora is requesting a loan of US$ 625 to purchase necessary items such as hair products, wigs, and cosmetics for her salon.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
