The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client.

The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional hair products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 50-year-old widow who has six children. She lost her husband 8 years ago through a car accident. As a single parent, the responsibility of the children rests squarely upon her shoulders. Through hard work, Rose has been able to support four children so they could finish high school.

For the past twenty years, Rose has been trading in maize and gari. Gari is produced from cassava, and it is one of the dietary carbohydrate supplements. She obtains her supplies from the farming communities and sells retail to her customers. She plans to use the loan to buy maize and gari in bulk, so she can meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children's educational fees.

Rose is a member of a community group called First King Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: Buy bulk of maize and gari in bulk and resell

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is 55 years old. She is married with three children. She lives with her family at Obuasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a merchant who has been selling lace clothes, women's slippers, and dressing bags for the past thirty years. She is requesting a loan to augment her working capital to buy more lace clothes, slippers and dressing bags to sell. She believes the loan will enable her to augment her income to support her family.

Alima is a member of a community group called "Mamuli" Trust Group. Members of this group guarantee and provide assistance to one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy more lace clothes, slippers, and dressing bags

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Salamatu is a 47-year-old mother of seven children. All the children currently attend school. Salamatu enjoys selling and takes pride in serving her customers. She has been selling maize and gari for 10 years to support her family. Gari is produced from cassava and it is one of the dietary carbohydrate supplements. She obtains her supplies from the farming communities and sells retail to her customers.

She plans to use the loan to buy maize and gari in bulk in order to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children's educational fees. Salamatu is a member of a community group called Adekyensroma Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: Buy maize and gari in bulk and resell retail

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 49 years old. She is divorced, and has nine children. She is resourceful and very enterprising. Through her business, she has supported four of her children, who have graduated from high school. The other four are currently in school. She operates a local restaurant and sells local foods, like cooked rice and banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is eaten with hot pepper or soup.

Elizabeth says that prices of raw materials have gone up significantly, and she is no longer able to afford production costs. This has adversely affected production quality. She plans to use the loan to buy more raw materials like maize, rice, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. The loan can provide additional capital so she can increase production and still maintain quality.

Elizabeth is a member of a group called Adekyensroma Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: Buy more raw materials like maize, rice, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood to increase food production

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is a 41-year-old mother of five children, who are currently in school. Stella's business allows her to help her husband support their children in school. She has operated a seamstress shop for the past 20 years. She trains 14 young ladies in sewing, teaching them the skills she has and providing them with experience for their future careers. She sews all types of woman's clothing in various styles, such as kaba and slit, wedding dresses, and funeral clothes. (The picture shows Stella in the black outfit, with her apprentices.)

She plans to use the loan to buy more sewing materials like linen, thread, and thimbles, to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children in school and build her own place of work.

She is a member of the community group called Asomafo Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: Buy more sewing materials like linen, thread, and thimbles

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is 55 years old, divorced, and has seven children. Currently, only one of the children is in school; the others have completed school. Theresa enjoys selling, and she has many years of experience serving customers. She has been selling maize and yam for 30 years to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock from the farmers. This saves her from buying from middlemen, who buy from the farmers and resell at higher price.

She plans to use the loan to buy maize and yams in bulk so she can meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children, who are ready to enter university this year.

Theresa is a member of a community group called Isaac Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: Buy maize and yams in bulk to resell

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a 28-year-old young man. He is single and very dedicated to his work. He owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits etc. in his neighborhood.

Alex wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, spices, washing soaps and powders etc. to expand his business. He hopes to save more to build a shop since he operates out of a rented store which is very costly to him. He belongs to the community group called 'Mamuli Trust Group'. The group members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans on time.

loans.use: To more rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, spices, washing soaps and powders etc.

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte is 38 years old. She is a wife and mother of three children. Through her business, Charlotte has supported one of her children to finish senior high school, and the others are currently in school. She is a food vendor and sells 'kenkey' as well as maize.

Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. Charlotte has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey at breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials such as bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and also firewood.

Charlotte hopes to increase her savings to pay for her children's education. She belongs to the community group called St. Paul's Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia, is 34 years old, married, and has with two children, who attend school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother. Emelia helps her husband provide for the household by selling used clothing and shoes. In Ghana, there is a very big market selling used clothes, because brand new clothes are very expensive for poor people. Therefore, selling used clothing has created a market for many Ghanaian women like Emelia.

Emelia plans to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save more for her children's education and also to rent a store for her trading. She is member of the group called St. Pauls. Members agree to guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: Buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice F. is 34 years old. She is married with three kids. Her kids are in school. She lives with her family in Obuasi, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. Eunice is a very skillful and talented hair dresser. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, so she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products, such as weave-ons, pomade, shampoo, and activators, to serve her customers. She is a member of the community group called St. Paul's Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee loans for one another as social collateral and provide support to one another to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more hair products for her salon

loans.name: Alberto José

texts.es:
In the municipality of El Viejo in the city of Chinandega, señor Alberto Melendez is dedicated to his business, the “Espiritu Santo” medical laboratory clinic, which, due to his various efforts, he has managed to maintain and to some extent over time improve little by little. It is necessary to emphasize that, in the year since he started the business, he has managed to improve the conditions of his home.

Due to the fact that he has carried out this economic activity for a year, he has sought a way to bring better attention to the laboratory and for this he has requested a loan from Ceprodel to purchase work instruments and improve the location. With this loan he will benefit greatly and equally his beloved family also benefits.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En el municipio de El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega, el señorAlberto Melendez se dedica a su negocio delaboratorio clinico “Espiritu Santo” el cual debido a sus multiples esfuerzos ha logrado mantener y a medidida que el tiempo ha venido transcurriendo lo ha venido mejorando poco a poco. Es necesario destacar que desde hace un año que inició el negocio ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su hogar.

Debido a que está iniciando esta actividad economica por lo que lleva un año, ha buscado la manera dbrindar mejor atencion en el laboratorio y para esto ha solicitado un credito en Ceprodel para la compra de instrumentos de trabajo y mejora del local. Con este credito se beneficia grandemente y de igual forma su amada familia tambien es beneficiada

loans.use: To improve his medical clinic and buy instruments for his work.

loans.name: Azucena Concepción

texts.es:
Señora Azucena R. is a very hard-working lady whose work is the making of clothes. Having been a seamstress for various years, this is the only means with which she supports her children, offering them the necessary things of life.

Because of the difficult situation that has been present in their community, the municipality of El Viejo in Chinandega, for a long time, this very day endangering the welfare of her children, she has sought the support in Ceprodel to obtain a necessary loan that will permit her to do better in making a living in their humble home of habitation.

The loan requested will be used to purchase clothes and materials and supplies such as threads, fabrics, needles, etc. At present she is known as a faithful client of Ceprodel, having paid 21 loans in full on time and according to the agreement established with the institution.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Azucena R. es una dama muy esforzada cuya labor es la elaboracion de ropa habiendose dedicado al negocio de costurera desde hace varios años siendo este su unico sustento con el cual apoya a sus hijos brindandoles las condiciones necesarias de vida.

A pesar de su dificil situacion que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado en su comunidad en el municipio El Viejo en Chinandega, hoy en dia comprometida con el bienestar de sus hijos ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtrener creditos necesarios que le permitan salir adelante en el sustento de su humilde hogar de habitacion.

El credito solicitado lo utilizará para la compra de ropa y materiales e trabajo como lo son hilos, telas, agujas, etc. Actualmente se ha destacado como una fiel cliente de Ceprodel habiendo realizado 21 creditos pagados en tiempo y forma de aucerdo a lo establecido en la institucion.

loans.use: To buy cloth and materials for sewing such as thread, needles, etc.

loans.name: Edelmira Jamileth

texts.es:
Edelmira L. is a lady with a great spirit of self-improvement in her small grocery store business which is located in the municipality of El Viejo in the city of Chinandega. She is a person that five years ago started selling a few products but over time has managed to improve her conditions and diversify her products.

Today she has requested a loan from Ceprodel for the purpose of buying products to resell. It is necessary to emphasize that her efforts are due to her desire to offer a better standard of living to her two small children, which she has the obligation to maintain and support in all their needs.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Edelmira L. es una dama con un gran espiritu de superacion en su nego cio de pulperia el cual lo tiene ubicado en el municipio de El Viejo en la ciudad de Chinandega. Es una persona que desde hace cinco años inició vendiendo pocos productos pero a medida que el tiempo ha venido transcurriendo ha logrado mejorar su condicion y ha diversificado sus productos.

Hoy en dia ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un credito con el proposito de comprar sus productos para comercializarlos. Es necesario destacar que sus esfuerzos se deben a su interes por brindarles un mejor nivel de vida a sus dos pequeños hijos los cuales tiene la obligacion de mantener y apoyarlos en todas sus necesidades.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her grocery store.

loans.name: Herminia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Herminia del Socorro U. is a very hard-working lady whose work is selling of office supplies in her locality of the municipality of El Viejo in the city of Chinandega in the beautiful nation of Nicaragua.

Since she started the business, she has managed to supply the needs of her home of habitation and has maintained her small son of school age. Her larger dreams are that her small child should become a great professional and for this she works hard in her business.

For these reasons Señora Herminia seeks the support of Ceprodel to obtain the loan necessary for the purchase of her merchandise and in this way to continue with the maintenance of her home and of her small son.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Herminia del Socorro U. es una dama muy esforzada cuya labor es la venta de productos de librería comercializados en su localidad en el municipio de El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega de la bella nacion de Nicaragua.

Desde que inició el negocio ha logrado suplir las necesidades de su hogar de habitacion y ha mantenido a su pequeño hijo en edad escolar.Sus mayores sueños son que su pequeño llegue a ser un gran profesional y para ello se esfuerza grandemente en su negocio.

Por estas razones es que la señora Herminia busca el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener el credito necesario para la compra de su mercaderia y asi continuar con el mantenimiento de su hogar y de su pequeño hijo.

loans.use: To buy office supplies for resale.

loans.name: Jasmina Iveth

texts.es:
In the municipality of El Viejo of the city of Chinandega, Señora Jasmina G. has been dedicated for four years to her small general store business, offering all kinds of products from food to personal and home products. She is a mother of two children who has the obligation to maintain them and also to provide them with the needs for their studies.

Today the need that this lady faces is the urgency to buy the products for her general store, and for this reason she has requested a loan from Ceprodel for the purchase of said products, so that she may continue with her business that so requires investment for its respective development.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En el municipio de El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Jasmina G. se dedica desde hace cuatro años al negocio de pulperia ofreciendo todo tipo de productos desde comestibles hasta productos personales y del hogar. Es madre de dos hijos los cuales tiene la obligacion de mantener y ademas de proporcionarles las necesidades para sus estudios.

Hoy en dia la necesidad que esta dama atraviesa es la urgencia de comprar los productos para su pulperia y opr este motivo acude a Cerpodel para obtener el credito necesario para la compra de dichos productos y asi continuar con su negocio que tanto requiere de inversion para su respectivo desarrollo.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her small general store.

loans.name: Johana Francisca

texts.es:
Señora Johana L. is native of the municipality El Viejo of the city of Chinandega and is very vigorously dedicated to the business of the making and sale of tortillas which she markets from her own house of habitation in the municipality.

It is important to emphasize that from very early in the morning she creates her tortillas to offer to clients. Today, due to the fact that she has a small son of school age that she must maintain, she has requested a loan from Ceprodel to obtain the commodities for the making of the tortillas and in this way to continue offering the necessary conditions for study to her small son.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Johana L. es originaria del municipio El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega y se dedica muy esforzadamente al negocio de elaboracion y venta de tortillas las cuales las comercializa en su propia casa de habitacion en el municipio.

Es importante destacar que desde muy temprano por la mañana ella elabora sus tortillas para ofrecerla a los clientes. Hoy en dia debido a que tiene un pequeño hijo en edad escolar que mantener, ha solicitado un credito en Ceprodel para obtener su materia prima para la elaboracion de las tortillas y asi continuar brindandole las condiciones de estudio necesarias a su pequeño.

loans.use: To buy corn and firewood for the making of tortillas.

loans.name: Milagros Del Socorro

texts.es:
Señora Milagro del Socorro L. is dedicated to the business of selling various products, having her own general shore where she markets from her house of habitation in the municipality of El Viejo in the city of Chinandega. It is important to emphasize that she is a mother with two children which she has the obligation to maintain and to offer the conditions for their development.

The market of Señora Milagro has been improving little by little due to the fact that she has very wisely requested loans from Ceprodel to improve the business. Today once more she has requested a loan to permit her to purchase of her products in order to offer them for sale and in this way improve her economic condition and do well in her business. It is her dream to become a great merchant and in this way to do well making a living for her home.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Milagro del Socorro L. se dedica al negocio de venta de productos varios teneiendo su prodipa pulperia la cual comercializa en su casa de habitacion en el municipio El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega. Es importante destacar que ella es una madre con dos hijos los cuales tiene la obligacion de mantener y de brindarle las condiciones para su desarrollo.

La ferreteria de la señora Milagro ha venido mejorando poco a poco debido a que muy sabiamente ella ha solicitado creditos en Ceprodel para mejorar el negocio. Hoy en dia una vez mas ha acudido para solicitar un credito el cual le permita la compra de sus productos para ofrecerlos y de esta forma mejorar su condicion economica y salir adelante en su negocio. Son sus sueños llegar a convertirse en una gran comerciante y asi salir adelante llevando el sustento a su hogar de habitación.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her general store.

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Ngo Thi C. joined the TYM Fund since 1999. Before she joined the Fund, she faced a lot of difficulties in doing business because of lack of starting fund. After several years of investment in raising animals and knitting hats, her family economy improves. Currently, there are several clothing workshops in her area. She applied to be a worker, earning 100 USD/ month. She wants to also raise animals at home, beside working in the workshop, to earn more money. Her husband is a hard worker and helps her a lot. Beside working on the rice field, he also works and earns 100 USD/month. She has 3 children who are still going to school. This time, she wants to borrow 550 USD to invest in raising animals and fix the farming utilities. The family’s average income is 300 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

 Chị Ngô Thị Chấu tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 1999. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn vì thiếu vốn .Qua các năm vay vốn chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và đan mũ kinh tế dần dần nâng lên. Hiên nay ở địa phương nhiều công ty may được thành lập chị xin vào may gia công cho các xí nghiệp may thu nhập 1,5 triệu đồng / tháng . Chị muốn ngoài thời gian đi làm chị tâp chung chăn nuôi thêm để phát triển kinh tế. Chồng chị là người chịu khó biết chia sẻ công việc cùng gia đình. Hiện tại ngoài công việc làm ruộng anh còn đi làm thuê thu nhập bình quân 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Chị có 3 con hiện đang còn nhỏ và trong độ tuổi ăn học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và sửa chữa chuồng trại. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising animals

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. C. Thi Tran has been participating in the Fund since 1999, like many others in a region where the main source of income is farming. She works as a tailor making gloves. When first joining the Fund, she borrowed money to buy a sewing machine and fabric to make gloves. She does not need to spend time marketing and selling her products because a company has placed orders for her gloves. In the years since she has been participating in the Fund and investing in buying fabric, her family’s finances have improved gradually, but markedly. The money that she is able to save goes to buying essentials for her family and to send her two children to school. In this round of funding she is requesting 9,000,000 VND to continue investing in buying fabric to make gloves. The family’s average income is 4,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Chiêu tham gia quỹ từ năm 1999, cũng giống như bao thành viên khác tại địa phương nguồn thu nhập chính là làm ruộng, chị sống tại làng nghề may gang tay . Khi tham gia vào Quỹ chị đã vay vốn đầu tư vốn mua máy khâu và vải để may. Các sản phẩm của chị làm ra đều không phải mất thời gian đi bán vì các công ty đã đến đặt hàng. Qua các năm tham gia vay vốn chị đầu tư vào mua vải may gang tay kinh tế gia đình chị đã dần dần nâng lên rõ rệt. Số tiền tích lũy được chị đã đầu tư mua sắm trang thiết bị trong gia đình và đầu tư cho 2 con chị đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào mua vải để may gang tay. Thu nhập bình quân. 4.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: buying fabric to make gloves

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. T. Thi Hoan joined the Fund in 2001. She has many years of experience in making sesame rice crackers. In the 8 years that the family has been in the Fund, the family has always invested in this trade. During the first few years when the borrowed amounts were still small, the family only used the money to buy rice and continued to use simple handheld equipment. After two rounds of funding and the family’s finances had improved, she was able to use money she had saved up along with a loan from the Fund to buy an grinding machine for powder. Since they had obtained this machine, the cracker-making process is much more convenient and take less time with less effort, but still produce quality products. Currently she is living with her husband and son; her son works as labor for hire and brings in a stable monthly income of 2,000,000 VND. In this round of funding she is requesting 15,000,000 VND to buy more rice and a breeding pig to raise. Their average monthly income is 6,000,000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoàng Thị Thục tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2001. Có nhiều năm kinh nghiệm trong nghề làm bánh đa. Trải qua gần 8 năm vay vốn của Quỹ gia đình chị đều đầu tư vốn vào làm nghề. Những năm đầu tiên khi vốn vay còn nhỏ gia đình chị chỉ đầu tư vào mua gạo còn các máy móc vẫn còn thủ công. Sau 2 vòng vốn kinh tế gia đình chị đã thay đổi chị đã tích lũy được một số vốn kết hợp cùng với vay vốn của Quỹ gia đình chị đã mua được 1 chiếc máy say bột, từ khi có máy say công việc làm bánh của gia đình chị thuận tiện hơn không phải mất nhiều thời gian và công sức mà hiệu quả vẫn cao. Hiện tai chị đang sống cùng vợ chồng con trai, con trai chị cũng đi làm thuê thu nhập hàng tháng đều đặn 2.000.000đ. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua gao làm bánh và mua lợn giống để chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Buy rice and a breeding pig

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. M. Thi Nguyen, 32 years old, has been participating in the Fund since 2006. The family’s finances are encountering many difficulties; her husband works as labor for hire and she stays home to take care of their young children and work the fields. The farming work does not take up all her time, so she planned with her husband to join the Fund to start a home business and supplement the family’s income. The project she decided to invest in was making statues from plaster. The work is not too arduous, but the profit is still relatively high. In subsequent rounds of funding she always invested in buying more plaster. Since she has been in the Fund and doing this trade, the family’s finances have improved greatly, and she still has time to do farm work and take care of her children. In this round of funding she is requesting 9,000,000 VND to buy more plaster. Their average income is 4,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị M. 32 tuổi, tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 2006. Kinh tế gia đình còn gặp nhiều khó khăn con còn nhỏ chồng đi làm thuê còn chị ở nhà nuôi con. Công việc làm ruộng cùng nhàn rỗi nên chị đã bàn bạc cùng chồng tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn để chị ở nhà làm thêm tăng thu nhập cho gia đình. Dự án mà chị đầu tư vốn là làm tượng bằng thạch cao, công việc không vất vả mà thu nhập cũng tương đối cao nên các vòng vốn chị đều vay để đầu tư mua thạch cao làm tượng. Từ khi chị vay vốn và làm nghề kinh tế gia đình chị đã phát triển rất nhiều, đồng thời chị vẫn có thời gian làm ruộng kết hợp chăm sóc con. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 9.000.000đ để mua thạch cao. Thu nhập bình quân. 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Buy more plaster to make statues

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. H. Thi Nguyen joined the Fund in 2007. Her family lives in a house facing a main street, which is very convenient for running a business. She first joined the Fund to borrow money to invest in buying fruits to sell; at first she only sold small quantities to serve people in the area. After one round of funding and seeing that the business had very high profits, she invested more money to expand the store with many more types of fruits. Her husband buys and brings home the inventory of goods, and she runs the store and sells the fruits. Besides sales at the store, she also sells to traders who supply the local markets around the area, and also has contracts to supply fruits for family gatherings, events, and ceremonies. The family’s finances are slowly improving and her is also very happy with their business. She has two small school-age children. In this round of funding she is requesting 9,000,000 VND to continue investing in the fruits business. Their average income is 5,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hương tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2007, gia đình chị sống ở cạnh đường liên xã nên rất thuận tiện cho việc buôn bán. Năm 2007 chị tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn về đầu tư mua hoa quả, ban đầu chị cũng chỉ buôn bán nhỏ lẻ phục vụ bà con quanh địa phương. Trải qua 1 vòng vốn thấy rằng việc buôn bán thu nhấp rất cao, nên chị đã đầu tư thêm nhiều vốn mở rộng cửa hàng với nhiều loại hoa quả khác nhau. Chồng chị chuyên đi lấy hàng về và chị là người bán, ngoài việc bán lẻ chị cũng chuyên bán buôn cho các con buôn tại các khu chợ lẻ quanh vùng, và nhận hợp đồng cung cấp hoa quả cho các hộ gia đình có công việc như hiếu, hỷ.....Kinh tế gia đình chị từng bước phát triển và chị cũng rất hài lòng với việc kinh doanh của gia đình. Chị có 2 con còn nhỏ đang trong độ tuổi ăn học. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào buôn bán hoa quả. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Invest in fruits retail, trading business

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Y. Thi Do, 50 years old, joined the Fund in 2007.  In the first round of funding she borrowed 3,000,000 VND to invest in running a general store.  Her family’s store is the only one operating in the region, so their business is in a very favorable position.  When people in the area need to buy various goods, they always come to her family’s store.  With the business going so well, the family’s wish is to expand the store in the future and sell additional items such as beer, wine, and snacks to meet the local demand.  Her husband, besides working in the fields, also work as labor for hire to bring in an income of 1,500,000 VND a month.  In this round of funding she is requesting 9,000,000 VND to invest in the store.  Their average month income is 5,000,000 VND.  
Translated from Vietnamese by Chi NguY., Kiva volunteer.
Chị Đỗ Thị Yến  50 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2007. Vòng vốn ban đầu chị  vay 3.000.000đ đầu tư vốn vào kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa. Với việc kinh doanh này hiện tại ở địa phương chị chỉ có gia đình chị vì vậy công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị rất thuận lợi. Khi người dân trong địa phương có nhu cầu mua các mặt hàng thì họ đều tìm đến gia đình chị. Với công việc kinh doanh thuận lợi như vậy nên nguyện vọng của gia đình chị trong tương lai sẽ mở rộng thêm các mặt hàng như bia, rượu và bánh kẹo để đáp ứng như cầu tại địa phương. Chồng chị ngoài những công việc làm ruộng anh còn đi làm thuê thu nhập hàng tháng 1.500.000đ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Invest in store, expand and buy more goods

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trần Thị Ngân - 27 years old - joined the TYM Fund in 2005. Before joining the fund, her family's financial situation was challenging because they had young children and were completely on their own. When they joined the fund, she worked hard for a loan to invest into a livestock rearing business. She used her first loan of 3,000,000 VND to purchase pigs. The investment produced more than 1 ton of pork, which they sold. She saved some of the funds and used the rest to purchase piglets.

After the family borrowed funds to invest in a livestock rearing business, their financial situation has significantly improved. Not only do they have enough to cover their daily living costs, but the family also tries to save and build a reserve - little by little. Her husband works as a hired hand with an income of 70,000 VND per day. Currently, her family has a plan to renovate the pig pen to expand their business.

Their average income is 4,000,000 VND per month. For this loan, she is seeking 10,000,000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Ngân 27 tuổi, tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 2005. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn do con nhỏ và phải tự lập hoàn toàn, khi tham gia vào Quỹ chị đã mạnh giạn vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, Vòng vốn ban đầu chị vay 3.000.000đ chị đã mua lợn giống, sau khi hết vòng vốn thì gia đình chị cũng đã xuất chuồng hơn 1 tấn lợn thịt, số tiền thu được từ bán lợn lại được chị đầu tư vào mua con giống và tiết kiệm. Từ khi vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi kinh tế gia đình chị đã khá hơn rất nhiều, không chỉ đủ trang trải cuốc sống sinh hoạt hàng ngày mà gia đình chị còn tích lũy được số tiền tiết kiệm nho nhỏ, chồng chị đi làm thuê thu nhập 70.000đồng/ngày. Tới đây gia đình chị có kế hoạch sửa sang chuồng trại để đầu tư mô hình chăn nuôi với quy mô lớn hơn. Thu nhập bình quân. 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay. 10.000.000đ.

loans.use: Raising Livestock

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Lê Thị Nhân - 44 years old - joined the TYM Fund in 2006. She is more destitute than others in her community - she lost her husband at a young age and therefore she has had to bear the the weight of all household matters on her own shoulders. Refusing to simply accept her situation as destiny, she worked hard to make a living.

Participation in the Fund has helped her raise money to invest in agricultural businesses of raising livestock and growing crops. All of her determination has ben rewarded. The livestock rearing business produces about 2 tons of pork (pig meat) each year. Also, her yard is quite spacious therefore the annual income from her fruit-bearing plants can be as much as 20,000,000 VND.

All her children have been raised through the struggles of those months and years. Currently, all her children are grown, very obedient and able to assist with all family matters. Also, her eldest is employed with a stable monthly income of 1,500,000 VND.

For this loan, she would like to raise 10,000,000 VND to make their breeding facilities more convenient for their livestock rearing business. Their average income is 4,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Nhân 44 tuổi tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 2006. Vất vả hơn so với các thành viên khác trong cụm, chồng mất sớm nên mọi công việc lo toan của gia đình đều chút lên đội vai chị, không chịu khuất phục trước số phận chị đã tần tạo chịu khó làm ăn. Tham gia vào Quỹ chị đã vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và chồng trọt, mọi cố gắng của chị cũng được đền đáp, công việc chăn nuôi thuận lợi hàng năm chị xuất ra thị trường bình quân 2 tấn lợn thịt. Với diện tích vườn khá rộng nên thu nhập từ chồng cây ăn quả hàng năm của gia đình chị cũng lên tới 20.000.000đ. Các con chị cũng đã lớn dần theo năm tháng. Hiện tại các con chị đã lớn và rất ngoan đều có thể giúp đỡ chị mọi công việc trong ra đình, và con lớn của chị cũng đi làm ngoài thu nhập hàng tháng ổn định 1.500.000đ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 10.000.000đ sửa chuồng trại để thuận tiện cho việc chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân. 4.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Improve breeding facilities for livestock rearing business.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trần Thị N. joined the TYM Fund in 2003. Before participating in the fund, her family had financial difficulties because they had to care for their young children. Now she only cares for one child who is in high school. In the past few years, her family has borrowed money to raise pigs and chicken. Their income from raising livestock is 2,000,000 VND per month. Currently, she has 9 pigs and 200 chicken which she is prepared to sell.

She has been successful with raising livestock which is how she has been able to provide for her child in high school. Additionally, she carefully monitors her finances to save when possible. Her eldest also has a job now and a steady income of 2,000,000 VND per month.

For this loan, she wishes to borrow 6,000,000 VND to invest in her animal rearing business. Their average income is 5,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị N. tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 2003. Khi trưa tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình khó khăn do nuôi các con ăn học, hiện nay chị đang nuôi một con học đại học. Trong các năm qua gia đình chị vay vốn về chị dùng để chăn nuôi lợn, gà thu nhập từ chăn nuôi của gia đình chị là: 2.000.000đ/ tháng . Hiện nay trong chuồng nhà chị đang có 9 con lợn chuẩn bị xuất và 200 con gà thịt, chăn nuôi hiệu quả nên chị đã có đủ điều kiện để nuôi con học đại học, ngoài ra chị vẫn tích lũy được tiền để tiết kiệm, Con lớn của chị hiện tại cũng đã có công ăn việc làm và cho thu nhập ổn định 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 6.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Raising Pigs and Chicken

loans.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Duong Thi X. - 41 years old - joined the TYM Fund in 1998. Her family's financial situation has completely changed during the last ten years of their participation in the fund. Her family has experienced good results from their investment into rearing livestock and they have been able to save up to build a house with four rooms which are quite spacious.

Today, in addition to their livestock rearing, she and her husband gather and sell scraps which provides an income of 1,000,000 VND per day. Her family hopes to expand their breeding facilities and purchase more pigs to raise.

For this loan, she seeks 12,000,000 VND to renovate the breeding facilities and purchase more livestock. Their average income was 5,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Dương Thị Xuân 41 tuổi, tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 1998. Trải qua 10 năm tham gia vào Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị đã thay đổi rõ dệt. Từ việc đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi đem lại hiệu quả cao gia đình chị đã tích lũy được số tiền tiết kiệm và chị đã xây được 1 ngôi nhà 4 gian khá khang trang. Hiện nay ngoài công việc chăn nuôi vợ chồng chị còn đầu tư vốn đi thu mua phế liệu về bán thu nhập 100.0000đ/ ngày. Với mong muốn của gia đình chị là đầu tư mở rộng chuồng trại và mua giống lợn với số lượng lớn về chăn nuôi. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay.12.000.000đ sửa sang chuồng trại và mua giống lợn. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
K. joined the TYM Fund in 1998. She has two children, both of whom are grown. Before participating in the fund, the family experienced financial hardships due to the lack of capital for their business.

She used her first loan to purchase scraps and resell them for an income of 60,000 VND per day. She now hopes to borrow capital to invest in renovating their breeding facilities to rear livestock because she does not have the physical capacity to continue the scrap retail business.

For this loan, K. hopes to raise 9,000,000 VND. Her income is 2,500,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Khánh tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 1998. Gia đình chị có 2 con đều đã trưởng thành Trước khi tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn khó khăn do thiếu vốn làm ăn. Sau khi vay vốn về chị dùng để đi thu mua phế liệu về bán cho thu nhập 60.000 đồng/ ngày. Đến nay do không có đủ sức khoẻ để đi thu mua phế liệu nên chị mong muốn được vay thêm vốn để sửa sang chuồng trại và đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000 đ. Thu nhập 2.500.000 đ/ th áng

loans.use: Raising livestock

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hiên tham gia vào quỹ từ năm 1998 sau khi tham gia vào Quỹ chị mạnh dạn vay vốn về để đi thu mua phế liệu. Với thu nhập  từ việc đi thu mua phế liệu khoảng 100.000 đồng/ ngày, sau 10 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương  kinh tế gia đình chị đã dần đi lên anh chị đã làm được nhà mái bằng và mua sắm được một số trang thiết bị trong gia đình. Hiện nay chồng chị đã  không đ ủ  sức  khoẻ  để  tiếp  tục  đi thu mua phế  liệu  nên chị muốn vay vốn về mua 3 con bò cho chồng nuôi còn chị tiếp tục  công việc đi thu mua phế liệu về bán. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000 đ.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hiên joined the TYM Fund in 1998. After joining the fund, she worked hard to borrow money to purchase and resell scraps. With the income of about 100,000 VND from reselling scraps, after 10 years of participating in the fund, the family's finanicial situation has gone up. They have been about to make a level roof and purchase some personal things for the family. Currently, her husband doesn't have enough strength to continue their scrap reselling business therefore she wants to borrow a loan to purchase three cows for her husband to care for, while she continues their scrap reselling business. For this loan, she would like to raise 15,000,000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Livestock (cattle)

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Hương  tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2003. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình  chị còn nhiều khó khăn, các con còn nhỏ. Sau khi tham gia vào Quỹ  anh chị vay vốn về chủ yếu để đi thu mua phế liệu. Công việc thu mua phế liệu  cho thu nhập 70 ngìn đồng/ngày . Để  có thêm vốn  đầu  tư  đi mua phế  liệu  , phát  triển  kinh t ế  gia đình  và  có  điều  kiện đầu  tư  tốt  hơn cho các  con đi học  vòng  vốn  tới  chị  mong muốn được vay 6.000.000. Thu nhập  2.000.000/ tháng
texts.en:
Mrs. H. became a member of TYM Fund in 2003. Before joining TYM Fund, Mrs. H.’s family ran into a lot of financial difficulties. Since she joined TYM, Mrs. H. has used all the loans to collect wastes and resell them, from which she earns about 70000 VND per day. With a view to expand her business so that she can earn more income to send her kids to school, Mrs. H. would like to ask for 6.000.000 VND ($375) in this round. Her family’s monthly income is 2.000.000 VND.


Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Torn

texts.en:
Mrs. Torn L. (49) is a widow with five adopted children: three sons and two daughters. One of her daughters works in a restaurant, and the other one is a silk weaver. One of her sons is a ferryboat worker, the second is a monk, and the third studies in a local school. All of her children also help her in the farming business. Torn and her children live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Torn has been a silk weaver for thirty years. She sells her finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Besides her weaving business, she grows rice as well. She needs the money to continue her existing business and repair the broken part of her house.

She is requesting a loan of US$1200 to purchase silk materials for weaving and to purchase rice seeds and fertilizer for growing rice. The remainder of the money she will use to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving, grow rice and repair part of her house.

loans.name: Ek

texts.en:
Ek K., age 54, is a widow and originally from Prey Veng, but has a business selling vegetables in the market at Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She makes $5 in profits a day.  She told a loan officer that when she first started selling various kinds of vegetables her business was not going well, and since she was a new seller, she only had a few customers who supported her. But her business has improved since she has diversified her products, and now she has many customers. She lives with her three children who work as a translator and garment factory workers.

Mrs. Ek has requested a loan from Kiva via Credit to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport her products from her home to the market, which will reduce the cost she spends everyday on a motor-taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport her products from her home to the market.

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun S., age 40, has a business selling chickens in the market and lives in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. On average, she makes around $4 each day. She has four children, two of whom are students and the other two are employed by a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Kun S. included.

She has requested a loan of $500 to purchase a cow to help her farm. This will reduce her costs since she used to use a hand-tractor to plow her land.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase cows to help her farm.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
Nan C., age 37, runs a business selling a variety of biscuits at school to earn approximately $1.60 of profit a day. Her husband is a cow dealer, earning around $10 in revenue each day. This couple has three children and all of them are students. To make the business more lucrative, Mrs. C. would like to loan from Kiva via Credit, a local partner, to purchase more cows for her husband's business. This will increase the family's income.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more cows for her husband's business.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou C., age 57, owns a plot of land growing rice and makes around $1.50 of profit a day. Her husband is a construction foreman who builds houses. Normally he earns around $2 of profit each day. This couple has three children, one of them is a student and the two others are garment workers.

Mrs. Ou C. would like to request a loan from Kiva via Credit, a local partner, to purchase more construction tools such as an electrical saw and a cement mixer. (Her husband is pictured becaused Mrs. Ou C. was not available.)

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more construction tools such as an electrical saw and a cement mixer for her husband's business.

loans.name: Lon

texts.en:
Mrs. Lon R. (48) and her husband, Mr. Choeun Reach (58), who live about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1975 and have nine children: four sons and five daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home. Five of their children work in a garment factory and the other three children study in a local school.

Mrs. Lon and her husband have been farming since 1979. They grow many types of fruits, vegetables, and crops in their farm not so far from home. They sell the produce to the middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell at market. The couple lacks the money to purchase a motorcycle for their children drive to their work in Phnom Penh. Therefore, Lon is requesting a loan of $500 to go towards the purchase of a motorbike which their children can use to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle for her children drive to work.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Sin C., age 36, grows rice and earns around $2 of profit a day. Her husband has a business collecting the villagers' harvest and plowing their farmland. On average, he makes about $3 of profit per day. This couple has three children and all of them are students.
Mrs. Sin C. would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a hand-tractor for her husband. This will allow family to use the hand-tractor to earn more profit to support the family. (Mrs. Sin C. is pictured with her husband.)

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: Mrs. Sin Chenda would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a hand-tractor for her husband.

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va S., age 49, is a widow and lives with her three children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She earns around $2 of profit per day from selling water. One of her children is a student and the two others are employed. She has been selling water for over 20 years. She used to use a cart to transfer the water but currently she owns a small truck to transport the water.  The truck is currently broken so she needs a loan from Kiva via Credit, a local partner, to fix the truck. She believes that once the truck is fixed, her business can go smoothly again.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: She hopes this loan can help fix her truck.

loans.name: Duch

texts.en:
Duch S., 49, is married and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She is a tailor and earns around $2 of profit per day. Her husband has been a farmer since 1985. He grows rice and the output he collects annually is just enough to support his family. This couple has four children and all of them are employed as garment workers.

Mrs. Duch S. would like a loan of US $1,000 from Kiva via Credit, a local partner, to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a business as a motor-taxi driver and the remaining amount will be used to raise pigs to sell.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a business as a motor-taxi driver and the remainder will be used to raise pigs to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokh Khen Village Bank Group

texts.en: The Village Bank, which consists of seventeen members, is located in BoE. Krum Leu Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Sokh K. is the Village Bank President and she is a pig breeder. Mrs. Sokh K. faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to purchase pig food to feed her two pigs. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Oum Ros, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support his family. He also assists his wife in her business when he has free time from his work. Mrs. Sokh K. is 41 years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children are car washing workers, while the youngest one is attending the local school. (A man who is in the photo is pictured instead of his wife because his wife is very busy with her work.)

loans.use: To purchase pig food to feed her two pigs.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan S., age 57, lives in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 1998, she and her husband, Bun Sophat, age 56, have been vendors selling a variety of vegetables to earn a living and is able to earn up to US$2 of profit per day. Before this business, the couple used to be farmers, but they stopped because there was no irrigation system in their village and farming depended a lot on the weather. According to the couple, “I cannot collect more output unless the weather condition is good.”  Due to difficulties such as bad weather, they have changed their work to selling vegetables instead. Together, the couple has two children and all of them have different work to support themselves. The oldest son is a taxi-driver and the daughter works as a housekeeper in Malaysia, making US$6 per day.

Mrs. Chan is seeking a loan of US$1,000 to build a new stand that is bigger to sell vegetables, as the old one was unreliable and too small. The money will also increase their inventory so they can meet their customers' demand for vegetables. (Mrs. Chan S. is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To replace an unreliable stand and diversify the products to meet the customers' demand.

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Mr. Lorn L. (61) and his wife, Mrs. Hauly Thaung (56) who live along Tonle Basac River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1979 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home and the youngest son is construction worker.

Mr. Lorn has been a mason and wooden house builder for fifteen years. His wife is not employed, and instead stays at home to do housework. Currently, Lorn's construction materials are old and broken so he needs to buy new materials to replace the old equipment. Therefore, Lorn is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase some new tools for his business. He will use the rest of the money to help his daughter with her grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and grocery items.

loans.name: Mrs. Duch Thoeun Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty-one members founded a Village Bank which is located in Khsom Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Duch T. was born in 1971.  She has three children who are all attending school; they are 14, 10 and 8 years old.  Mrs. Duch T. and her husband, Mr. Keo Ra, are fishermen. They gather fish in the local lake but they now do not have enough fishing equipment.  Therefore Mrs. Duch T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fish nets in order to gather fish.

loans.use: To buy fish nets in order to gather fish.

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Som S., age 61, is a widow and lives in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2006, she has been selling clothes in Phnom Penh to earn a living and is able to earn up to US$5 of profit per day. She told a loan officer that she used to be a farmer before she started selling clothes.  She stopped because her children got married and no longer lived with her, so there was no one to help her farm.  Her new business uses less labor and makes more profit than farming.  Currently, she still has one child and an old mother who are under her care.

Mrs. Som is seeking a loan of US$500 to invest in her business by ordering more clothes to sell. In the future, if she has enough money, she will purchase a stand to reduce the monthly fee she pays.

loans.use: To invest in her business by ordering more clothes to sell.
